    82 
    83 /* AddressSanitizer exposes additional functions for manually marking
    84    memory as poisoned/unpoisoned.  When ASan is enabled and the needed
    85    header is available, memory is poisoned when:
    86 
    87    * An ablock is freed (lisp_align_free), or ablocks are initially
    88    allocated (lisp_align_malloc).
    89    * An interval_block is initially allocated (make_interval).
    90    * A dead INTERVAL is put on the interval free list
    91    (sweep_intervals).
    92    * A sdata is marked as dead (sweep_strings, pin_string).
    93    * An sblock is initially allocated (allocate_string_data).
    94    * A string_block is initially allocated (allocate_string).
    95    * A dead string is put on string_free_list (sweep_strings).
    96    * A float_block is initially allocated (make_float).
    97    * A dead float is put on float_free_list.
    98    * A cons_block is initially allocated (Fcons).
    99    * A dead cons is put on cons_free_list (sweep_cons).
   100    * A dead vector is put on vector_free_list (setup_on_free_list),
   101    or a new vector block is allocated (allocate_vector_from_block).
   102    Accordingly, objects reused from the free list are unpoisoned.
   103 
   104    This feature can be disabled wtih the run-time flag
   105    `allow_user_poisoning' set to zero.  */
   106 #if ADDRESS_SANITIZER && defined HAVE_SANITIZER_ASAN_INTERFACE_H \
   107   && !defined GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
   108 # define GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS 1
   109 # include <sanitizer/asan_interface.h>
   110 #else
   111 # define GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS 0
   112 #endif
   113 
   114 /* GC_CHECK_MARKED_OBJECTS means do sanity checks on allocated objects.
   115    We turn that on by default when ENABLE_CHECKING is defined;
   116    define GC_CHECK_MARKED_OBJECTS to zero to disable.  */
   117 
   118 #if defined ENABLE_CHECKING && !defined GC_CHECK_MARKED_OBJECTS
   119 # define GC_CHECK_MARKED_OBJECTS 1
   120 #endif
   121 
   122 /* GC_MALLOC_CHECK defined means perform validity checks of malloc'd
   123    memory.  Can do this only if using gmalloc.c and if not checking
   124    marked objects.  */
   125 
   126 #if (defined SYSTEM_MALLOC || defined DOUG_LEA_MALLOC \
   127      || defined HYBRID_MALLOC || GC_CHECK_MARKED_OBJECTS)
   128 #undef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
   129 #endif
   130 
   131 #include <unistd.h>
   132 #include <fcntl.h>
   133 
   134 #ifdef USE_GTK
   135 # include "gtkutil.h"
   136 #endif
   137 #ifdef WINDOWSNT
   138 #include "w32.h"
   139 #include "w32heap.h"    /* for sbrk */
   140 #endif
   141 
   142 /* A type with alignment at least as large as any object that Emacs
   143    allocates.  This is not max_align_t because some platforms (e.g.,
   144    mingw) have buggy malloc implementations that do not align for
   145    max_align_t.  This union contains types of all GCALIGNED_STRUCT
   146    components visible here.  */
   147 union emacs_align_type
   148 {
   149   struct frame frame;
   150   struct Lisp_Bignum Lisp_Bignum;
   151   struct Lisp_Bool_Vector Lisp_Bool_Vector;
   152   struct Lisp_Char_Table Lisp_Char_Table;
   153   struct Lisp_CondVar Lisp_CondVar;
   154   struct Lisp_Finalizer Lisp_Finalizer;
   155   struct Lisp_Float Lisp_Float;
   156   struct Lisp_Hash_Table Lisp_Hash_Table;
   157   struct Lisp_Marker Lisp_Marker;
   158   struct Lisp_Misc_Ptr Lisp_Misc_Ptr;
   159   struct Lisp_Mutex Lisp_Mutex;
   160   struct Lisp_Overlay Lisp_Overlay;
   161   struct Lisp_Sub_Char_Table Lisp_Sub_Char_Table;
   162   struct Lisp_Subr Lisp_Subr;
   163   struct Lisp_Sqlite Lisp_Sqlite;
   164   struct Lisp_User_Ptr Lisp_User_Ptr;
   165   struct Lisp_Vector Lisp_Vector;
   166   struct terminal terminal;
   167   struct thread_state thread_state;
   168   struct window window;
   169 
   170   /* Omit the following since they would require including process.h
   171      etc.  In practice their alignments never exceed that of the
   172      structs already listed.  */
   173 #if 0
   174   struct Lisp_Module_Function Lisp_Module_Function;
   175   struct Lisp_Process Lisp_Process;
   176   struct save_window_data save_window_data;
   177   struct scroll_bar scroll_bar;
   178   struct xwidget_view xwidget_view;
   179   struct xwidget xwidget;
   180 #endif
   181 };
   182 
   183 /* MALLOC_SIZE_NEAR (N) is a good number to pass to malloc when
   184    allocating a block of memory with size close to N bytes.
   185    For best results N should be a power of 2.
   186 
   187    When calculating how much memory to allocate, GNU malloc (SIZE)
   188    adds sizeof (size_t) to SIZE for internal overhead, and then rounds
   189    up to a multiple of MALLOC_ALIGNMENT.  Emacs can improve
   190    performance a bit on GNU platforms by arranging for the resulting
   191    size to be a power of two.  This heuristic is good for glibc 2.26
   192    (2017) and later, and does not affect correctness on other
   193    platforms.  */
   194 
   195 #define MALLOC_SIZE_NEAR(n) \
   196   (ROUNDUP (max (n, sizeof (size_t)), MALLOC_ALIGNMENT) - sizeof (size_t))
   197 #ifdef __i386
   198 enum { MALLOC_ALIGNMENT = 16 };
   199 #else
   200 enum { MALLOC_ALIGNMENT = max (2 * sizeof (size_t), alignof (long double)) };
   201 #endif
   202 
   203 #ifdef DOUG_LEA_MALLOC
   204 
   205 /* Specify maximum number of areas to mmap.  It would be nice to use a
   206    value that explicitly means "no limit".  */
   207 
   208 # define MMAP_MAX_AREAS 100000000
   209 
   210 /* A pointer to the memory allocated that copies that static data
   211    inside glibc's malloc.  */
   212 static void *malloc_state_ptr;
   213 
   214 /* Restore the dumped malloc state.  Because malloc can be invoked
   215    even before main (e.g. by the dynamic linker), the dumped malloc
   216    state must be restored as early as possible using this special hook.  */
   217 static void
   218 malloc_initialize_hook (void)
   219 {
   220   static bool malloc_using_checking;
   221 
   222   if (! initialized)
   223     {
   224 # ifdef GNU_LINUX
   225       my_heap_start ();
   226 # endif
   227       malloc_using_checking = getenv ("MALLOC_CHECK_") != NULL;
   228     }
   229   else
   230     {
   231       if (!malloc_using_checking)
   232         {
   233           /* Work around a bug in glibc's malloc.  MALLOC_CHECK_ must be
   234              ignored if the heap to be restored was constructed without
   235              malloc checking.  Can't use unsetenv, since that calls malloc.  */
   236           char **p = environ;
   237           if (p)
   238             for (; *p; p++)
   239               if (strncmp (*p, "MALLOC_CHECK_=", 14) == 0)
   240                 {
   241                   do
   242                     *p = p[1];
   243                   while (*++p);
   244 
   245                   break;
   246                 }
   247         }
   248 
   249       if (malloc_set_state (malloc_state_ptr) != 0)
   250         emacs_abort ();
   251       alloc_unexec_post ();
   252     }
   253 }
   254 
   255 /* Declare the malloc initialization hook, which runs before 'main' starts.
   256    EXTERNALLY_VISIBLE works around Bug#22522.  */
   257 typedef void (*voidfuncptr) (void);
   258 # ifndef __MALLOC_HOOK_VOLATILE
   259 #  define __MALLOC_HOOK_VOLATILE
   260 # endif
   261 voidfuncptr __MALLOC_HOOK_VOLATILE __malloc_initialize_hook EXTERNALLY_VISIBLE
   262   = malloc_initialize_hook;
   263 
   264 #endif
   265 
   266 #if defined DOUG_LEA_MALLOC || defined HAVE_UNEXEC
   267 
   268 /* Allocator-related actions to do just before and after unexec.  */
   269 
   270 void
   271 alloc_unexec_pre (void)
   272 {
   273 # ifdef DOUG_LEA_MALLOC
   274   malloc_state_ptr = malloc_get_state ();
   275   if (!malloc_state_ptr)
   276     fatal ("malloc_get_state: %s", strerror (errno));
   277 # endif
   278 }
   279 
   280 void
   281 alloc_unexec_post (void)
   282 {
   283 # ifdef DOUG_LEA_MALLOC
   284   free (malloc_state_ptr);
   285 # endif
   286 }
   287 
   288 # ifdef GNU_LINUX
   289 
   290 /* The address where the heap starts.  */
   291 void *
   292 my_heap_start (void)
   293 {
   294   static void *start;
   295   if (! start)
   296     start = sbrk (0);
   297   return start;
   298 }
   299 # endif
   300 
   301 #endif
   302 
   303 /* Mark, unmark, query mark bit of a Lisp string.  S must be a pointer
   304    to a struct Lisp_String.  */
   305 
   306 #define XMARK_STRING(S)         ((S)->u.s.size |= ARRAY_MARK_FLAG)
   307 #define XUNMARK_STRING(S)       ((S)->u.s.size &= ~ARRAY_MARK_FLAG)
   308 #define XSTRING_MARKED_P(S)     (((S)->u.s.size & ARRAY_MARK_FLAG) != 0)
   309 
   310 #define XMARK_VECTOR(V)         ((V)->header.size |= ARRAY_MARK_FLAG)
   311 #define XUNMARK_VECTOR(V)       ((V)->header.size &= ~ARRAY_MARK_FLAG)
   312 #define XVECTOR_MARKED_P(V)     (((V)->header.size & ARRAY_MARK_FLAG) != 0)
   313 
   314 /* Default value of gc_cons_threshold (see below).  */
   315 
   316 #define GC_DEFAULT_THRESHOLD (100000 * word_size)
   317 
   318 /* Global variables.  */
   319 struct emacs_globals globals;
   320 
   321 /* maybe_gc collects garbage if this goes negative.  */
   322 
   323 EMACS_INT consing_until_gc;
   324 
   325 #ifdef HAVE_PDUMPER
   326 /* Number of finalizers run: used to loop over GC until we stop
   327    generating garbage.  */
   328 int number_finalizers_run;
   329 #endif
   330 
   331 /* True during GC.  */
   332 
   333 bool gc_in_progress;
   334 
   335 /* System byte and object counts reported by GC.  */
   336 
   337 /* Assume byte counts fit in uintptr_t and object counts fit into
   338    intptr_t.  */
   339 typedef uintptr_t byte_ct;
   340 typedef intptr_t object_ct;
   341 
   342 /* Large-magnitude value for a threshold count, which fits in EMACS_INT.
   343    Using only half the EMACS_INT range avoids overflow hassles.
   344    There is no need to fit these counts into fixnums.  */
   345 #define HI_THRESHOLD (EMACS_INT_MAX / 2)
   346 
   347 /* Number of live and free conses etc. counted by the most-recent GC.  */
   348 
   349 static struct gcstat
   350 {
   351   object_ct total_conses, total_free_conses;
   352   object_ct total_symbols, total_free_symbols;
   353   object_ct total_strings, total_free_strings;
   354   byte_ct total_string_bytes;
   355   object_ct total_vectors, total_vector_slots, total_free_vector_slots;
   356   object_ct total_floats, total_free_floats;
   357   object_ct total_intervals, total_free_intervals;
   358   object_ct total_buffers;
   359 } gcstat;
   360 
   361 /* Points to memory space allocated as "spare", to be freed if we run
   362    out of memory.  We keep one large block, four cons-blocks, and
   363    two string blocks.  */
   364 
   365 static char *spare_memory[7];
   366 
   367 /* Amount of spare memory to keep in large reserve block, or to see
   368    whether this much is available when malloc fails on a larger request.  */
   369 
   370 #define SPARE_MEMORY (1 << 14)
   371 
   372 /* Initialize it to a nonzero value to force it into data space
   373    (rather than bss space).  That way unexec will remap it into text
   374    space (pure), on some systems.  We have not implemented the
   375    remapping on more recent systems because this is less important
   376    nowadays than in the days of small memories and timesharing.  */
   377 
   378 EMACS_INT pure[(PURESIZE + sizeof (EMACS_INT) - 1) / sizeof (EMACS_INT)] = {1,};
   379 #define PUREBEG (char *) pure
   380 
   381 /* Pointer to the pure area, and its size.  */
   382 
   383 static char *purebeg;
   384 static ptrdiff_t pure_size;
   385 
   386 /* Number of bytes of pure storage used before pure storage overflowed.
   387    If this is non-zero, this implies that an overflow occurred.  */
   388 
   389 static ptrdiff_t pure_bytes_used_before_overflow;
   390 
   391 /* Index in pure at which next pure Lisp object will be allocated..  */
   392 
   393 static ptrdiff_t pure_bytes_used_lisp;
   394 
   395 /* Number of bytes allocated for non-Lisp objects in pure storage.  */
   396 
   397 static ptrdiff_t pure_bytes_used_non_lisp;
   398 
   399 /* If positive, garbage collection is inhibited.  Otherwise, zero.  */
   400 
   401 intptr_t garbage_collection_inhibited;
   402 
   403 /* The GC threshold in bytes, the last time it was calculated
   404    from gc-cons-threshold and gc-cons-percentage.  */
   405 static EMACS_INT gc_threshold;
   406 
   407 /* If nonzero, this is a warning delivered by malloc and not yet
   408    displayed.  */
   409 
   410 const char *pending_malloc_warning;
   411 
   412 /* Pointer sanity only on request.  FIXME: Code depending on
   413    SUSPICIOUS_OBJECT_CHECKING is obsolete; remove it entirely.  */
   414 #ifdef ENABLE_CHECKING
   415 #define SUSPICIOUS_OBJECT_CHECKING 1
   416 #endif
   417 
   418 #ifdef SUSPICIOUS_OBJECT_CHECKING
   419 struct suspicious_free_record
   420 {
   421   void *suspicious_object;
   422   void *backtrace[128];
   423 };
   424 static void *suspicious_objects[32];
   425 static int suspicious_object_index;
   426 struct suspicious_free_record suspicious_free_history[64] EXTERNALLY_VISIBLE;
   427 static int suspicious_free_history_index;
   428 /* Find the first currently-monitored suspicious pointer in range
   429    [begin,end) or NULL if no such pointer exists.  */
   430 static void *find_suspicious_object_in_range (void *begin, void *end);
   431 static void detect_suspicious_free (void *ptr);
   432 #else
   433 # define find_suspicious_object_in_range(begin, end) ((void *) NULL)
   434 # define detect_suspicious_free(ptr) ((void) 0)
   435 #endif
   436 
   437 /* Maximum amount of C stack to save when a GC happens.  */
   438 
   439 #ifndef MAX_SAVE_STACK
   440 #define MAX_SAVE_STACK 16000
   441 #endif
   442 
   443 /* Buffer in which we save a copy of the C stack at each GC.  */
   444 
   445 #if MAX_SAVE_STACK > 0
   446 static char *stack_copy;
   447 static ptrdiff_t stack_copy_size;
   448 
   449 /* Copy to DEST a block of memory from SRC of size SIZE bytes,
   450    avoiding any address sanitization.  */
   451 
   452 static void * ATTRIBUTE_NO_SANITIZE_ADDRESS
   453 no_sanitize_memcpy (void *dest, void const *src, size_t size)
   454 {
   455   if (! ADDRESS_SANITIZER)
   456     return memcpy (dest, src, size);
   457   else
   458     {
   459       size_t i;
   460       char *d = dest;
   461       char const *s = src;
   462       for (i = 0; i < size; i++)
   463         d[i] = s[i];
   464       return dest;
   465     }
   466 }
   467 
   468 #endif /* MAX_SAVE_STACK > 0 */
   469 
   470 static void unchain_finalizer (struct Lisp_Finalizer *);
   471 static void mark_terminals (void);
   472 static void gc_sweep (void);
   473 static Lisp_Object make_pure_vector (ptrdiff_t);
   474 static void mark_buffer (struct buffer *);
   475 
   476 #if !defined REL_ALLOC || defined SYSTEM_MALLOC || defined HYBRID_MALLOC
   477 static void refill_memory_reserve (void);
   478 #endif
   479 static void compact_small_strings (void);
   480 static void free_large_strings (void);
   481 extern Lisp_Object which_symbols (Lisp_Object, EMACS_INT) EXTERNALLY_VISIBLE;
   482 
   483 static bool vector_marked_p (struct Lisp_Vector const *);
   484 static bool vectorlike_marked_p (union vectorlike_header const *);
   485 static void set_vectorlike_marked (union vectorlike_header *);
   486 static bool interval_marked_p (INTERVAL);
   487 static void set_interval_marked (INTERVAL);
   488 
   489 /* When scanning the C stack for live Lisp objects, Emacs keeps track of
   490    what memory allocated via lisp_malloc and lisp_align_malloc is intended
   491    for what purpose.  This enumeration specifies the type of memory.  */
   492 
   493 enum mem_type
   494 {
   495   MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP,
   496   MEM_TYPE_CONS,
   497   MEM_TYPE_STRING,
   498   MEM_TYPE_SYMBOL,
   499   MEM_TYPE_FLOAT,
   500   /* Since all non-bool pseudovectors are small enough to be
   501      allocated from vector blocks, this memory type denotes
   502      large regular vectors and large bool pseudovectors.  */
   503   MEM_TYPE_VECTORLIKE,
   504   /* Special type to denote vector blocks.  */
   505   MEM_TYPE_VECTOR_BLOCK,
   506   /* Special type to denote reserved memory.  */
   507   MEM_TYPE_SPARE
   508 };
   509 
   510 static bool
   511 deadp (Lisp_Object x)
   512 {
   513   return BASE_EQ (x, dead_object ());
   514 }
   515 
   516 #ifdef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
   517 
   518 enum mem_type allocated_mem_type;
   519 
   520 #endif /* GC_MALLOC_CHECK */
   521 
   522 /* A node in the red-black tree describing allocated memory containing
   523    Lisp data.  Each such block is recorded with its start and end
   524    address when it is allocated, and removed from the tree when it
   525    is freed.
   526 
   527    A red-black tree is a balanced binary tree with the following
   528    properties:
   529 
   530    1. Every node is either red or black.
   531    2. Every leaf is black.
   532    3. If a node is red, then both of its children are black.
   533    4. Every simple path from a node to a descendant leaf contains
   534    the same number of black nodes.
   535    5. The root is always black.
   536 
   537    When nodes are inserted into the tree, or deleted from the tree,
   538    the tree is "fixed" so that these properties are always true.
   539 
   540    A red-black tree with N internal nodes has height at most 2
   541    log(N+1).  Searches, insertions and deletions are done in O(log N).
   542    Please see a text book about data structures for a detailed
   543    description of red-black trees.  Any book worth its salt should
   544    describe them.  */
   545 
   546 struct mem_node
   547 {
   548   /* Children of this node.  These pointers are never NULL.  When there
   549      is no child, the value is MEM_NIL, which points to a dummy node.  */
   550   struct mem_node *left, *right;
   551 
   552   /* The parent of this node.  In the root node, this is NULL.  */
   553   struct mem_node *parent;
   554 
   555   /* Start and end of allocated region.  */
   556   void *start, *end;
   557 
   558   /* Node color.  */
   559   enum {MEM_BLACK, MEM_RED} color;
   560 
   561   /* Memory type.  */
   562   enum mem_type type;
   563 };
   564 
   565 /* Root of the tree describing allocated Lisp memory.  */
   566 
   567 static struct mem_node *mem_root;
   568 
   569 /* Lowest and highest known address in the heap.  */
   570 
   571 static void *min_heap_address, *max_heap_address;
   572 
   573 /* Sentinel node of the tree.  */
   574 
   575 static struct mem_node mem_z;
   576 #define MEM_NIL &mem_z
   577 
   578 static struct mem_node *mem_insert (void *, void *, enum mem_type);
   579 static void mem_insert_fixup (struct mem_node *);
   580 static void mem_rotate_left (struct mem_node *);
   581 static void mem_rotate_right (struct mem_node *);
   582 static void mem_delete (struct mem_node *);
   583 static void mem_delete_fixup (struct mem_node *);
   584 static struct mem_node *mem_find (void *);
   585 
   586 /* Addresses of staticpro'd variables.  Initialize it to a nonzero
   587    value if we might unexec; otherwise some compilers put it into
   588    BSS.  */
   589 
   590 Lisp_Object const *staticvec[NSTATICS]
   591 #ifdef HAVE_UNEXEC
   592 = {&Vpurify_flag}
   593 #endif
   594   ;
   595 
   596 /* Index of next unused slot in staticvec.  */
   597 
   598 int staticidx;
   599 
   600 static void *pure_alloc (size_t, int);
   601 
   602 /* Return PTR rounded up to the next multiple of ALIGNMENT.  */
   603 
   604 static void *
   605 pointer_align (void *ptr, int alignment)
   606 {
   607   return (void *) ROUNDUP ((uintptr_t) ptr, alignment);
   608 }
   609 
   610 /* Extract the pointer hidden within O.  */
   611 
   612 static ATTRIBUTE_NO_SANITIZE_UNDEFINED void *
   613 XPNTR (Lisp_Object a)
   614 {
   615   return (BARE_SYMBOL_P (a)
   616           ? (char *) lispsym + (XLI (a) - LISP_WORD_TAG (Lisp_Symbol))
   617           : (char *) XLP (a) - (XLI (a) & ~VALMASK));
   618 }
   619 
   620 static void
   621 XFLOAT_INIT (Lisp_Object f, double n)
   622 {
   623   XFLOAT (f)->u.data = n;
   624 }
   625 
   626 /* Account for allocation of NBYTES in the heap.  This is a separate
   627    function to avoid hassles with implementation-defined conversion
   628    from unsigned to signed types.  */
   629 static void
   630 tally_consing (ptrdiff_t nbytes)
   631 {
   632   consing_until_gc -= nbytes;
   633 }
   634 
   635 #ifdef DOUG_LEA_MALLOC
   636 static bool
   637 pointers_fit_in_lispobj_p (void)
   638 {
   639   return (UINTPTR_MAX <= VAL_MAX) || USE_LSB_TAG;
   640 }
   641 
   642 static bool
   643 mmap_lisp_allowed_p (void)
   644 {
   645   /* If we can't store all memory addresses in our lisp objects, it's
   646      risky to let the heap use mmap and give us addresses from all
   647      over our address space.  We also can't use mmap for lisp objects
   648      if we might dump: unexec doesn't preserve the contents of mmapped
   649      regions.  */
   650   return pointers_fit_in_lispobj_p () && !will_dump_with_unexec_p ();
   651 }
   652 #endif
   653 
   654 /* Head of a circularly-linked list of extant finalizers. */
   655 struct Lisp_Finalizer finalizers;
   656 
   657 /* Head of a circularly-linked list of finalizers that must be invoked
   658    because we deemed them unreachable.  This list must be global, and
   659    not a local inside garbage_collect, in case we GC again while
   660    running finalizers.  */
   661 struct Lisp_Finalizer doomed_finalizers;
   662 
   663 
   664 /************************************************************************
   665                                 Malloc
   666  ************************************************************************/
   667 
   668 #if defined SIGDANGER || (!defined SYSTEM_MALLOC && !defined HYBRID_MALLOC)
   669 
   670 /* Function malloc calls this if it finds we are near exhausting storage.  */
   671 
   672 void
   673 malloc_warning (const char *str)
   674 {
   675   pending_malloc_warning = str;
   676 }
   677 
   678 #endif
   679 
   680 /* Display an already-pending malloc warning.  */
   681 
   682 void
   683 display_malloc_warning (void)
   684 {
   685   call3 (intern ("display-warning"),
   686          intern ("alloc"),
   687          build_string (pending_malloc_warning),
   688          intern (":emergency"));
   689   pending_malloc_warning = 0;
   690 }
   691 
   692 /* Called if we can't allocate relocatable space for a buffer.  */
   693 
   694 void
   695 buffer_memory_full (ptrdiff_t nbytes)
   696 {
   697   /* If buffers use the relocating allocator, no need to free
   698      spare_memory, because we may have plenty of malloc space left
   699      that we could get, and if we don't, the malloc that fails will
   700      itself cause spare_memory to be freed.  If buffers don't use the
   701      relocating allocator, treat this like any other failing
   702      malloc.  */
   703 
   704 #ifndef REL_ALLOC
   705   memory_full (nbytes);
   706 #else
   707   /* This used to call error, but if we've run out of memory, we could
   708      get infinite recursion trying to build the string.  */
   709   xsignal (Qnil, Vmemory_signal_data);
   710 #endif
   711 }
   712 
   713 /* A common multiple of the positive integers A and B.  Ideally this
   714    would be the least common multiple, but there's no way to do that
   715    as a constant expression in C, so do the best that we can easily do.  */
   716 #define COMMON_MULTIPLE(a, b) \
   717   ((a) % (b) == 0 ? (a) : (b) % (a) == 0 ? (b) : (a) * (b))
   718 
   719 /* Alignment needed for memory blocks that are allocated via malloc
   720    and that contain Lisp objects.  On typical hosts malloc already
   721    aligns sufficiently, but extra work is needed on oddball hosts
   722    where Emacs would crash if malloc returned a non-GCALIGNED pointer.  */
   723 enum { LISP_ALIGNMENT = alignof (union { union emacs_align_type x;
   724                                          GCALIGNED_UNION_MEMBER }) };
   725 verify (LISP_ALIGNMENT % GCALIGNMENT == 0);
   726 
   727 /* True if malloc (N) is known to return storage suitably aligned for
   728    Lisp objects whenever N is a multiple of LISP_ALIGNMENT.  In
   729    practice this is true whenever alignof (max_align_t) is also a
   730    multiple of LISP_ALIGNMENT.  This works even for buggy platforms
   731    like MinGW circa 2020, where alignof (max_align_t) is 16 even though
   732    the malloc alignment is only 8, and where Emacs still works because
   733    it never does anything that requires an alignment of 16.  */
   734 enum { MALLOC_IS_LISP_ALIGNED = alignof (max_align_t) % LISP_ALIGNMENT == 0 };
   735 
   736 /* If compiled with XMALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT_CHECK, define a symbol
   737    BLOCK_INPUT_IN_MEMORY_ALLOCATORS that is visible to the debugger.
   738    If that variable is set, block input while in one of Emacs's memory
   739    allocation functions.  There should be no need for this debugging
   740    option, since signal handlers do not allocate memory, but Emacs
   741    formerly allocated memory in signal handlers and this compile-time
   742    option remains as a way to help debug the issue should it rear its
   743    ugly head again.  */
   744 #ifdef XMALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT_CHECK
   745 bool block_input_in_memory_allocators EXTERNALLY_VISIBLE;
   746 static void
   747 malloc_block_input (void)
   748 {
   749   if (block_input_in_memory_allocators)
   750     block_input ();
   751 }
   752 static void
   753 malloc_unblock_input (void)
   754 {
   755   if (block_input_in_memory_allocators)
   756     {
   757       int err = errno;
   758       unblock_input ();
   759       errno = err;
   760     }
   761 }
   762 # define MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT malloc_block_input ()
   763 # define MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT malloc_unblock_input ()
   764 #else
   765 # define MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT ((void) 0)
   766 # define MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT ((void) 0)
   767 #endif
   768 
   769 #define MALLOC_PROBE(size)                      \
   770   do {                                          \
   771     if (profiler_memory_running)                \
   772       malloc_probe (size);                      \
   773   } while (0)
   774 
   775 static void *lmalloc (size_t, bool) ATTRIBUTE_MALLOC_SIZE ((1));
   776 static void *lrealloc (void *, size_t);
   777 
   778 /* Like malloc but check for no memory and block interrupt input.  */
   779 
   780 void *
   781 xmalloc (size_t size)
   782 {
   783   void *val;
   784 
   785   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
   786   val = lmalloc (size, false);
   787   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
   788 
   789   if (!val)
   790     memory_full (size);
   791   MALLOC_PROBE (size);
   792   return val;
   793 }
   794 
   795 /* Like the above, but zeroes out the memory just allocated.  */
   796 
   797 void *
   798 xzalloc (size_t size)
   799 {
   800   void *val;
   801 
   802   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
   803   val = lmalloc (size, true);
   804   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
   805 
   806   if (!val)
   807     memory_full (size);
   808   MALLOC_PROBE (size);
   809   return val;
   810 }
   811 
   812 /* Like realloc but check for no memory and block interrupt input.  */
   813 
   814 void *
   815 xrealloc (void *block, size_t size)
   816 {
   817   void *val;
   818 
   819   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
   820   /* Call lmalloc when BLOCK is null, for the benefit of long-obsolete
   821      platforms lacking support for realloc (NULL, size).  */
   822   if (! block)
   823     val = lmalloc (size, false);
   824   else
   825     val = lrealloc (block, size);
   826   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
   827 
   828   if (!val)
   829     memory_full (size);
   830   MALLOC_PROBE (size);
   831   return val;
   832 }
   833 
   834 
   835 /* Like free but block interrupt input.  */
   836 
   837 void
   838 xfree (void *block)
   839 {
   840   if (!block)
   841     return;
   842   if (pdumper_object_p (block))
   843     return;
   844   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
   845   free (block);
   846   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
   847   /* We don't call refill_memory_reserve here
   848      because in practice the call in r_alloc_free seems to suffice.  */
   849 }
   850 
   851 
   852 /* Other parts of Emacs pass large int values to allocator functions
   853    expecting ptrdiff_t.  This is portable in practice, but check it to
   854    be safe.  */
   855 verify (INT_MAX <= PTRDIFF_MAX);
   856 
   857 
   858 /* Allocate an array of NITEMS items, each of size ITEM_SIZE.
   859    Signal an error on memory exhaustion, and block interrupt input.  */
   860 
   861 void *
   862 xnmalloc (ptrdiff_t nitems, ptrdiff_t item_size)
   863 {
   864   eassert (0 <= nitems && 0 < item_size);
   865   ptrdiff_t nbytes;
   866   if (ckd_mul (&nbytes, nitems, item_size) || SIZE_MAX < nbytes)
   867     memory_full (SIZE_MAX);
   868   return xmalloc (nbytes);
   869 }
   870 
   871 
   872 /* Reallocate an array PA to make it of NITEMS items, each of size ITEM_SIZE.
   873    Signal an error on memory exhaustion, and block interrupt input.  */
   874 
   875 void *
   876 xnrealloc (void *pa, ptrdiff_t nitems, ptrdiff_t item_size)
   877 {
   878   eassert (0 <= nitems && 0 < item_size);
   879   ptrdiff_t nbytes;
   880   if (ckd_mul (&nbytes, nitems, item_size) || SIZE_MAX < nbytes)
   881     memory_full (SIZE_MAX);
   882   return xrealloc (pa, nbytes);
   883 }
   884 
   885 
   886 /* Grow PA, which points to an array of *NITEMS items, and return the
   887    location of the reallocated array, updating *NITEMS to reflect its
   888    new size.  The new array will contain at least NITEMS_INCR_MIN more
   889    items, but will not contain more than NITEMS_MAX items total.
   890    ITEM_SIZE is the size of each item, in bytes.
   891 
   892    ITEM_SIZE and NITEMS_INCR_MIN must be positive.  *NITEMS must be
   893    nonnegative.  If NITEMS_MAX is -1, it is treated as if it were
   894    infinity.
   895 
   896    If PA is null, then allocate a new array instead of reallocating
   897    the old one.
   898 
   899    Block interrupt input as needed.  If memory exhaustion occurs, set
   900    *NITEMS to zero if PA is null, and signal an error (i.e., do not
   901    return).
   902 
   903    Thus, to grow an array A without saving its old contents, do
   904    { xfree (A); A = NULL; A = xpalloc (NULL, &AITEMS, ...); }.
   905    The A = NULL avoids a dangling pointer if xpalloc exhausts memory
   906    and signals an error, and later this code is reexecuted and
   907    attempts to free A.  */
   908 
   909 void *
   910 xpalloc (void *pa, ptrdiff_t *nitems, ptrdiff_t nitems_incr_min,
   911          ptrdiff_t nitems_max, ptrdiff_t item_size)
   912 {
   913   ptrdiff_t n0 = *nitems;
   914   eassume (0 < item_size && 0 < nitems_incr_min && 0 <= n0 && -1 <= nitems_max);
   915 
   916   /* The approximate size to use for initial small allocation
   917      requests.  This is the largest "small" request for the GNU C
   918      library malloc.  */
   919   enum { DEFAULT_MXFAST = 64 * sizeof (size_t) / 4 };
   920 
   921   /* If the array is tiny, grow it to about (but no greater than)
   922      DEFAULT_MXFAST bytes.  Otherwise, grow it by about 50%.
   923      Adjust the growth according to three constraints: NITEMS_INCR_MIN,
   924      NITEMS_MAX, and what the C language can represent safely.  */
   925 
   926   ptrdiff_t n, nbytes;
   927   if (ckd_add (&n, n0, n0 >> 1))
   928     n = PTRDIFF_MAX;
   929   if (0 <= nitems_max && nitems_max < n)
   930     n = nitems_max;
   931 
   932   ptrdiff_t adjusted_nbytes
   933     = ((ckd_mul (&nbytes, n, item_size) || SIZE_MAX < nbytes)
   934        ? min (PTRDIFF_MAX, SIZE_MAX)
   935        : nbytes < DEFAULT_MXFAST ? DEFAULT_MXFAST : 0);
   936   if (adjusted_nbytes)
   937     {
   938       n = adjusted_nbytes / item_size;
   939       nbytes = adjusted_nbytes - adjusted_nbytes % item_size;
   940     }
   941 
   942   if (! pa)
   943     *nitems = 0;
   944   if (n - n0 < nitems_incr_min
   945       && (ckd_add (&n, n0, nitems_incr_min)
   946           || (0 <= nitems_max && nitems_max < n)
   947           || ckd_mul (&nbytes, n, item_size)))
   948     memory_full (SIZE_MAX);
   949   pa = xrealloc (pa, nbytes);
   950   *nitems = n;
   951   return pa;
   952 }
   953 
   954 
   955 /* Like strdup, but uses xmalloc.  */
   956 
   957 char *
   958 xstrdup (const char *s)
   959 {
   960   ptrdiff_t size;
   961   eassert (s);
   962   size = strlen (s) + 1;
   963   return memcpy (xmalloc (size), s, size);
   964 }
   965 
   966 /* Like above, but duplicates Lisp string to C string.  */
   967 
   968 char *
   969 xlispstrdup (Lisp_Object string)
   970 {
   971   ptrdiff_t size = SBYTES (string) + 1;
   972   return memcpy (xmalloc (size), SSDATA (string), size);
   973 }
   974 
   975 /* Assign to *PTR a copy of STRING, freeing any storage *PTR formerly
   976    pointed to.  If STRING is null, assign it without copying anything.
   977    Allocate before freeing, to avoid a dangling pointer if allocation
   978    fails.  */
   979 
   980 void
   981 dupstring (char **ptr, char const *string)
   982 {
   983   char *old = *ptr;
   984   *ptr = string ? xstrdup (string) : 0;
   985   xfree (old);
   986 }
   987 
   988 
   989 /* Like putenv, but (1) use the equivalent of xmalloc and (2) the
   990    argument is a const pointer.  */
   991 
   992 void
   993 xputenv (char const *string)
   994 {
   995   if (putenv ((char *) string) != 0)
   996     memory_full (0);
   997 }
   998 
   999 /* Return a newly allocated memory block of SIZE bytes, remembering
  1000    to free it when unwinding.  */
  1001 void *
  1002 record_xmalloc (size_t size)
  1003 {
  1004   void *p = xmalloc (size);
  1005   record_unwind_protect_ptr (xfree, p);
  1006   return p;
  1007 }
  1008 
  1009 
  1010 /* Like malloc but used for allocating Lisp data.  NBYTES is the
  1011    number of bytes to allocate, TYPE describes the intended use of the
  1012    allocated memory block (for strings, for conses, ...).  */
  1013 
  1014 #if ! USE_LSB_TAG
  1015 void *lisp_malloc_loser EXTERNALLY_VISIBLE;
  1016 #endif
  1017 
  1018 static void *
  1019 lisp_malloc (size_t nbytes, bool clearit, enum mem_type type)
  1020 {
  1021   register void *val;
  1022 
  1023   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
  1024 
  1025 #ifdef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
  1026   allocated_mem_type = type;
  1027 #endif
  1028 
  1029   val = lmalloc (nbytes, clearit);
  1030 
  1031 #if ! USE_LSB_TAG
  1032   /* If the memory just allocated cannot be addressed thru a Lisp
  1033      object's pointer, and it needs to be,
  1034      that's equivalent to running out of memory.  */
  1035   if (val && type != MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP)
  1036     {
  1037       Lisp_Object tem;
  1038       XSETCONS (tem, (char *) val + nbytes - 1);
  1039       if ((char *) XCONS (tem) != (char *) val + nbytes - 1)
  1040         {
  1041           lisp_malloc_loser = val;
  1042           free (val);
  1043           val = 0;
  1044         }
  1045     }
  1046 #endif
  1047 
  1048 #ifndef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
  1049   if (val && type != MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP)
  1050     mem_insert (val, (char *) val + nbytes, type);
  1051 #endif
  1052 
  1053   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
  1054   if (!val)
  1055     memory_full (nbytes);
  1056   MALLOC_PROBE (nbytes);
  1057   return val;
  1058 }
  1059 
  1060 /* Free BLOCK.  This must be called to free memory allocated with a
  1061    call to lisp_malloc.  */
  1062 
  1063 static void
  1064 lisp_free (void *block)
  1065 {
  1066   if (pdumper_object_p (block))
  1067     return;
  1068 
  1069   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
  1070 #ifndef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
  1071   struct mem_node *m = mem_find (block);
  1072 #endif
  1073   free (block);
  1074 #ifndef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
  1075   mem_delete (m);
  1076 #endif
  1077   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
  1078 }
  1079 
  1080 /*****  Allocation of aligned blocks of memory to store Lisp data.  *****/
  1081 
  1082 /* The entry point is lisp_align_malloc which returns blocks of at most
  1083    BLOCK_BYTES and guarantees they are aligned on a BLOCK_ALIGN boundary.  */
  1084 
  1085 /* Byte alignment of storage blocks.  */
  1086 #ifdef HAVE_UNEXEC
  1087 # define BLOCK_ALIGN (1 << 10)
  1088 #else  /* !HAVE_UNEXEC */
  1089 # define BLOCK_ALIGN (1 << 15)
  1090 #endif
  1091 verify (POWER_OF_2 (BLOCK_ALIGN));
  1092 
  1093 /* Use aligned_alloc if it or a simple substitute is available.
  1094    Aligned allocation is incompatible with unexmacosx.c, so don't use
  1095    it on Darwin if HAVE_UNEXEC.  */
  1096 
  1097 #if ! (defined DARWIN_OS && defined HAVE_UNEXEC)
  1098 # if (defined HAVE_ALIGNED_ALLOC                                        \
  1099       || (defined HYBRID_MALLOC                                         \
  1100           ? defined HAVE_POSIX_MEMALIGN                                 \
  1101           : !defined SYSTEM_MALLOC && !defined DOUG_LEA_MALLOC))
  1102 #  define USE_ALIGNED_ALLOC 1
  1103 # elif !defined HYBRID_MALLOC && defined HAVE_POSIX_MEMALIGN
  1104 #  define USE_ALIGNED_ALLOC 1
  1105 #  define aligned_alloc my_aligned_alloc /* Avoid collision with lisp.h.  */
  1106 static void *
  1107 aligned_alloc (size_t alignment, size_t size)
  1108 {
  1109   /* POSIX says the alignment must be a power-of-2 multiple of sizeof (void *).
  1110      Verify this for all arguments this function is given.  */
  1111   verify (BLOCK_ALIGN % sizeof (void *) == 0
  1112           && POWER_OF_2 (BLOCK_ALIGN / sizeof (void *)));
  1113   verify (MALLOC_IS_LISP_ALIGNED
  1114           || (LISP_ALIGNMENT % sizeof (void *) == 0
  1115               && POWER_OF_2 (LISP_ALIGNMENT / sizeof (void *))));
  1116   eassert (alignment == BLOCK_ALIGN
  1117            || (!MALLOC_IS_LISP_ALIGNED && alignment == LISP_ALIGNMENT));
  1118 
  1119   void *p;
  1120   return posix_memalign (&p, alignment, size) == 0 ? p : 0;
  1121 }
  1122 # endif
  1123 #endif
  1124 
  1125 /* Padding to leave at the end of a malloc'd block.  This is to give
  1126    malloc a chance to minimize the amount of memory wasted to alignment.
  1127    It should be tuned to the particular malloc library used.
  1128    On glibc-2.3.2, malloc never tries to align, so a padding of 0 is best.
  1129    aligned_alloc on the other hand would ideally prefer a value of 4
  1130    because otherwise, there's 1020 bytes wasted between each ablocks.
  1131    In Emacs, testing shows that those 1020 can most of the time be
  1132    efficiently used by malloc to place other objects, so a value of 0 can
  1133    still preferable unless you have a lot of aligned blocks and virtually
  1134    nothing else.  */
  1135 #define BLOCK_PADDING 0
  1136 #define BLOCK_BYTES \
  1137   (BLOCK_ALIGN - sizeof (struct ablocks *) - BLOCK_PADDING)
  1138 
  1139 /* Internal data structures and constants.  */
  1140 
  1141 #define ABLOCKS_SIZE 16
  1142 
  1143 /* An aligned block of memory.  */
  1144 struct ablock
  1145 {
  1146   union
  1147   {
  1148     char payload[BLOCK_BYTES];
  1149     struct ablock *next_free;
  1150   } x;
  1151 
  1152   /* ABASE is the aligned base of the ablocks.  It is overloaded to
  1153      hold a virtual "busy" field that counts twice the number of used
  1154      ablock values in the parent ablocks, plus one if the real base of
  1155      the parent ablocks is ABASE (if the "busy" field is even, the
  1156      word before the first ablock holds a pointer to the real base).
  1157      The first ablock has a "busy" ABASE, and the others have an
  1158      ordinary pointer ABASE.  To tell the difference, the code assumes
  1159      that pointers, when cast to uintptr_t, are at least 2 *
  1160      ABLOCKS_SIZE + 1.  */
  1161   struct ablocks *abase;
  1162 
  1163   /* The padding of all but the last ablock is unused.  The padding of
  1164      the last ablock in an ablocks is not allocated.  */
  1165 #if BLOCK_PADDING
  1166   char padding[BLOCK_PADDING];
  1167 #endif
  1168 };
  1169 
  1170 /* A bunch of consecutive aligned blocks.  */
  1171 struct ablocks
  1172 {
  1173   struct ablock blocks[ABLOCKS_SIZE];
  1174 };
  1175 
  1176 /* Size of the block requested from malloc or aligned_alloc.  */
  1177 #define ABLOCKS_BYTES (sizeof (struct ablocks) - BLOCK_PADDING)
  1178 
  1179 #define ABLOCK_ABASE(block) \
  1180   (((uintptr_t) (block)->abase) <= (1 + 2 * ABLOCKS_SIZE)       \
  1181    ? (struct ablocks *) (block)                                 \
  1182    : (block)->abase)
  1183 
  1184 /* Virtual `busy' field.  */
  1185 #define ABLOCKS_BUSY(a_base) ((a_base)->blocks[0].abase)
  1186 
  1187 /* Pointer to the (not necessarily aligned) malloc block.  */
  1188 #ifdef USE_ALIGNED_ALLOC
  1189 #define ABLOCKS_BASE(abase) (abase)
  1190 #else
  1191 #define ABLOCKS_BASE(abase) \
  1192   (1 & (intptr_t) ABLOCKS_BUSY (abase) ? abase : ((void **) (abase))[-1])
  1193 #endif
  1194 
  1195 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  1196 # define ASAN_POISON_ABLOCK(b) \
  1197   __asan_poison_memory_region (&(b)->x, sizeof ((b)->x))
  1198 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_ABLOCK(b) \
  1199   __asan_unpoison_memory_region (&(b)->x, sizeof ((b)->x))
  1200 #else
  1201 # define ASAN_POISON_ABLOCK(b) ((void) 0)
  1202 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_ABLOCK(b) ((void) 0)
  1203 #endif
  1204 
  1205 /* The list of free ablock.   */
  1206 static struct ablock *free_ablock;
  1207 
  1208 /* Allocate an aligned block of nbytes.
  1209    Alignment is on a multiple of BLOCK_ALIGN and `nbytes' has to be
  1210    smaller or equal to BLOCK_BYTES.  */
  1211 static void *
  1212 lisp_align_malloc (size_t nbytes, enum mem_type type)
  1213 {
  1214   void *base, *val;
  1215   struct ablocks *abase;
  1216 
  1217   eassert (nbytes <= BLOCK_BYTES);
  1218 
  1219   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
  1220 
  1221 #ifdef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
  1222   allocated_mem_type = type;
  1223 #endif
  1224 
  1225   if (!free_ablock)
  1226     {
  1227       int i;
  1228       bool aligned;
  1229 
  1230 #ifdef DOUG_LEA_MALLOC
  1231       if (!mmap_lisp_allowed_p ())
  1232         mallopt (M_MMAP_MAX, 0);
  1233 #endif
  1234 
  1235 #ifdef USE_ALIGNED_ALLOC
  1236       verify (ABLOCKS_BYTES % BLOCK_ALIGN == 0);
  1237       abase = base = aligned_alloc (BLOCK_ALIGN, ABLOCKS_BYTES);
  1238 #else
  1239       base = malloc (ABLOCKS_BYTES);
  1240       abase = pointer_align (base, BLOCK_ALIGN);
  1241 #endif
  1242 
  1243       if (base == 0)
  1244         {
  1245           MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
  1246           memory_full (ABLOCKS_BYTES);
  1247         }
  1248 
  1249       aligned = (base == abase);
  1250       if (!aligned)
  1251         ((void **) abase)[-1] = base;
  1252 
  1253 #ifdef DOUG_LEA_MALLOC
  1254       if (!mmap_lisp_allowed_p ())
  1255           mallopt (M_MMAP_MAX, MMAP_MAX_AREAS);
  1256 #endif
  1257 
  1258 #if ! USE_LSB_TAG
  1259       /* If the memory just allocated cannot be addressed thru a Lisp
  1260          object's pointer, and it needs to be, that's equivalent to
  1261          running out of memory.  */
  1262       if (type != MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP)
  1263         {
  1264           Lisp_Object tem;
  1265           char *end = (char *) base + ABLOCKS_BYTES - 1;
  1266           XSETCONS (tem, end);
  1267           if ((char *) XCONS (tem) != end)
  1268             {
  1269               lisp_malloc_loser = base;
  1270               free (base);
  1271               MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
  1272               memory_full (SIZE_MAX);
  1273             }
  1274         }
  1275 #endif
  1276 
  1277       /* Initialize the blocks and put them on the free list.
  1278          If `base' was not properly aligned, we can't use the last block.  */
  1279       for (i = 0; i < (aligned ? ABLOCKS_SIZE : ABLOCKS_SIZE - 1); i++)
  1280         {
  1281           abase->blocks[i].abase = abase;
  1282           abase->blocks[i].x.next_free = free_ablock;
  1283           ASAN_POISON_ABLOCK (&abase->blocks[i]);
  1284           free_ablock = &abase->blocks[i];
  1285         }
  1286       intptr_t ialigned = aligned;
  1287       ABLOCKS_BUSY (abase) = (struct ablocks *) ialigned;
  1288 
  1289       eassert ((uintptr_t) abase % BLOCK_ALIGN == 0);
  1290       eassert (ABLOCK_ABASE (&abase->blocks[3]) == abase); /* 3 is arbitrary */
  1291       eassert (ABLOCK_ABASE (&abase->blocks[0]) == abase);
  1292       eassert (ABLOCKS_BASE (abase) == base);
  1293       eassert ((intptr_t) ABLOCKS_BUSY (abase) == aligned);
  1294     }
  1295 
  1296   ASAN_UNPOISON_ABLOCK (free_ablock);
  1297   abase = ABLOCK_ABASE (free_ablock);
  1298   ABLOCKS_BUSY (abase)
  1299     = (struct ablocks *) (2 + (intptr_t) ABLOCKS_BUSY (abase));
  1300   val = free_ablock;
  1301   free_ablock = free_ablock->x.next_free;
  1302 
  1303 #ifndef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
  1304   if (type != MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP)
  1305     mem_insert (val, (char *) val + nbytes, type);
  1306 #endif
  1307 
  1308   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
  1309 
  1310   MALLOC_PROBE (nbytes);
  1311 
  1312   eassert (0 == ((uintptr_t) val) % BLOCK_ALIGN);
  1313   return val;
  1314 }
  1315 
  1316 static void
  1317 lisp_align_free (void *block)
  1318 {
  1319   struct ablock *ablock = block;
  1320   struct ablocks *abase = ABLOCK_ABASE (ablock);
  1321 
  1322   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
  1323 #ifndef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
  1324   mem_delete (mem_find (block));
  1325 #endif
  1326   /* Put on free list.  */
  1327   ablock->x.next_free = free_ablock;
  1328   ASAN_POISON_ABLOCK (ablock);
  1329   free_ablock = ablock;
  1330   /* Update busy count.  */
  1331   intptr_t busy = (intptr_t) ABLOCKS_BUSY (abase) - 2;
  1332   eassume (0 <= busy && busy <= 2 * ABLOCKS_SIZE - 1);
  1333   ABLOCKS_BUSY (abase) = (struct ablocks *) busy;
  1334 
  1335   if (busy < 2)
  1336     { /* All the blocks are free.  */
  1337       int i = 0;
  1338       bool aligned = busy;
  1339       struct ablock **tem = &free_ablock;
  1340       struct ablock *atop = &abase->blocks[aligned ? ABLOCKS_SIZE : ABLOCKS_SIZE - 1];
  1341       while (*tem)
  1342         {
  1343 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  1344           __asan_unpoison_memory_region (&(*tem)->x,
  1345                                          sizeof ((*tem)->x));
  1346 #endif
  1347           if (*tem >= (struct ablock *) abase && *tem < atop)
  1348             {
  1349               i++;
  1350               *tem = (*tem)->x.next_free;
  1351             }
  1352           else
  1353             tem = &(*tem)->x.next_free;
  1354         }
  1355       eassert ((aligned & 1) == aligned);
  1356       eassert (i == (aligned ? ABLOCKS_SIZE : ABLOCKS_SIZE - 1));
  1357 #ifdef USE_POSIX_MEMALIGN
  1358       eassert ((uintptr_t) ABLOCKS_BASE (abase) % BLOCK_ALIGN == 0);
  1359 #endif
  1360       free (ABLOCKS_BASE (abase));
  1361     }
  1362   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
  1363 }
  1364 
  1365 /* True if a malloc-returned pointer P is suitably aligned for SIZE,
  1366    where Lisp object alignment may be needed if SIZE is a multiple of
  1367    LISP_ALIGNMENT.  */
  1368 
  1369 static bool
  1370 laligned (void *p, size_t size)
  1371 {
  1372   return (MALLOC_IS_LISP_ALIGNED || (intptr_t) p % LISP_ALIGNMENT == 0
  1373           || size % LISP_ALIGNMENT != 0);
  1374 }
  1375 
  1376 /* Like malloc and realloc except return null only on failure,
  1377    the result is Lisp-aligned if SIZE is, and lrealloc's pointer
  1378    argument must be nonnull.  Code allocating C heap memory
  1379    for a Lisp object should use one of these functions to obtain a
  1380    pointer P; that way, if T is an enum Lisp_Type value and L ==
  1381    make_lisp_ptr (P, T), then XPNTR (L) == P and XTYPE (L) == T.
  1382 
  1383    If CLEARIT, arrange for the allocated memory to be cleared.
  1384    This might use calloc, as calloc can be faster than malloc+memset.
  1385 
  1386    On typical modern platforms these functions' loops do not iterate.
  1387    On now-rare (and perhaps nonexistent) platforms, the code can loop,
  1388    reallocating (typically with larger and larger sizes) until the
  1389    allocator returns a Lisp-aligned pointer.  This loop in
  1390    theory could repeat forever.  If an infinite loop is possible on a
  1391    platform, a build would surely loop and the builder can then send
  1392    us a bug report.  Adding a counter to try to detect any such loop
  1393    would complicate the code (and possibly introduce bugs, in code
  1394    that's never really exercised) for little benefit.  */
  1395 
  1396 static void *
  1397 lmalloc (size_t size, bool clearit)
  1398 {
  1399 #ifdef USE_ALIGNED_ALLOC
  1400   if (! MALLOC_IS_LISP_ALIGNED && size % LISP_ALIGNMENT == 0)
  1401     {
  1402       void *p = aligned_alloc (LISP_ALIGNMENT, size);
  1403       if (p)
  1404         {
  1405           if (clearit)
  1406             memclear (p, size);
  1407         }
  1408       else if (! (MALLOC_0_IS_NONNULL || size))
  1409         return aligned_alloc (LISP_ALIGNMENT, LISP_ALIGNMENT);
  1410       return p;
  1411     }
  1412 #endif
  1413 
  1414   while (true)
  1415     {
  1416       void *p = clearit ? calloc (1, size) : malloc (size);
  1417       if (laligned (p, size) && (MALLOC_0_IS_NONNULL || size || p))
  1418         return p;
  1419       free (p);
  1420       size_t bigger = size + LISP_ALIGNMENT;
  1421       if (size < bigger)
  1422         size = bigger;
  1423     }
  1424 }
  1425 
  1426 static void *
  1427 lrealloc (void *p, size_t size)
  1428 {
  1429   while (true)
  1430     {
  1431       p = realloc (p, size);
  1432       if (laligned (p, size) && (size || p))
  1433         return p;
  1434       size_t bigger = size + LISP_ALIGNMENT;
  1435       if (size < bigger)
  1436         size = bigger;
  1437     }
  1438 }
  1439 
  1440 
  1441 /***********************************************************************
  1442                          Interval Allocation
  1443  ***********************************************************************/
  1444 
  1445 /* Number of intervals allocated in an interval_block structure.  */
  1446 
  1447 enum { INTERVAL_BLOCK_SIZE
  1448          = ((MALLOC_SIZE_NEAR (1024) - sizeof (struct interval_block *))
  1449             / sizeof (struct interval)) };
  1450 
  1451 /* Intervals are allocated in chunks in the form of an interval_block
  1452    structure.  */
  1453 
  1454 struct interval_block
  1455 {
  1456   /* Place `intervals' first, to preserve alignment.  */
  1457   struct interval intervals[INTERVAL_BLOCK_SIZE];
  1458   struct interval_block *next;
  1459 };
  1460 
  1461 /* Current interval block.  Its `next' pointer points to older
  1462    blocks.  */
  1463 
  1464 static struct interval_block *interval_block;
  1465 
  1466 /* Index in interval_block above of the next unused interval
  1467    structure.  */
  1468 
  1469 static int interval_block_index = INTERVAL_BLOCK_SIZE;
  1470 
  1471 /* List of free intervals.  */
  1472 
  1473 static INTERVAL interval_free_list;
  1474 
  1475 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  1476 # define ASAN_POISON_INTERVAL_BLOCK(b)         \
  1477   __asan_poison_memory_region ((b)->intervals, \
  1478                                sizeof ((b)->intervals))
  1479 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_INTERVAL_BLOCK(b)         \
  1480   __asan_unpoison_memory_region ((b)->intervals, \
  1481                                  sizeof ((b)->intervals))
  1482 # define ASAN_POISON_INTERVAL(i) \
  1483   __asan_poison_memory_region ((i), sizeof (*(i)))
  1484 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_INTERVAL(i) \
  1485   __asan_unpoison_memory_region ((i), sizeof (*(i)))
  1486 #else
  1487 # define ASAN_POISON_INTERVAL_BLOCK(b) ((void) 0)
  1488 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_INTERVAL_BLOCK(b) ((void) 0)
  1489 # define ASAN_POISON_INTERVAL(i) ((void) 0)
  1490 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_INTERVAL(i) ((void) 0)
  1491 #endif
  1492 
  1493 /* Return a new interval.  */
  1494 
  1495 INTERVAL
  1496 make_interval (void)
  1497 {
  1498   INTERVAL val;
  1499 
  1500   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
  1501 
  1502   if (interval_free_list)
  1503     {
  1504       val = interval_free_list;
  1505       ASAN_UNPOISON_INTERVAL (val);
  1506       interval_free_list = INTERVAL_PARENT (interval_free_list);
  1507     }
  1508   else
  1509     {
  1510       if (interval_block_index == INTERVAL_BLOCK_SIZE)
  1511         {
  1512           struct interval_block *newi
  1513             = lisp_malloc (sizeof *newi, false, MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP);
  1514 
  1515           newi->next = interval_block;
  1516           ASAN_POISON_INTERVAL_BLOCK (newi);
  1517           interval_block = newi;
  1518           interval_block_index = 0;
  1519         }
  1520       val = &interval_block->intervals[interval_block_index++];
  1521       ASAN_UNPOISON_INTERVAL (val);
  1522     }
  1523 
  1524   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
  1525 
  1526   tally_consing (sizeof (struct interval));
  1527   intervals_consed++;
  1528   RESET_INTERVAL (val);
  1529   val->gcmarkbit = 0;
  1530   return val;
  1531 }
  1532 
  1533 
  1534 /* Mark Lisp objects in interval I.  */
  1535 
  1536 static void
  1537 mark_interval_tree_1 (INTERVAL i, void *dummy)
  1538 {
  1539   /* Intervals should never be shared.  So, if extra internal checking is
  1540      enabled, GC aborts if it seems to have visited an interval twice.  */
  1541   eassert (!interval_marked_p (i));
  1542   set_interval_marked (i);
  1543   mark_object (i->plist);
  1544 }
  1545 
  1546 /* Mark the interval tree rooted in I.  */
  1547 
  1548 static void
  1549 mark_interval_tree (INTERVAL i)
  1550 {
  1551   if (i && !interval_marked_p (i))
  1552     traverse_intervals_noorder (i, mark_interval_tree_1, NULL);
  1553 }
  1554 
  1555 /***********************************************************************
  1556                           String Allocation
  1557  ***********************************************************************/
  1558 
  1559 /* Lisp_Strings are allocated in string_block structures.  When a new
  1560    string_block is allocated, all the Lisp_Strings it contains are
  1561    added to a free-list string_free_list.  When a new Lisp_String is
  1562    needed, it is taken from that list.  During the sweep phase of GC,
  1563    string_blocks that are entirely free are freed, except two which
  1564    we keep.
  1565 
  1566    String data is allocated from sblock structures.  Strings larger
  1567    than LARGE_STRING_BYTES, get their own sblock, data for smaller
  1568    strings is sub-allocated out of sblocks of size SBLOCK_SIZE.
  1569 
  1570    Sblocks consist internally of sdata structures, one for each
  1571    Lisp_String.  The sdata structure points to the Lisp_String it
  1572    belongs to.  The Lisp_String points back to the `u.data' member of
  1573    its sdata structure.
  1574 
  1575    When a Lisp_String is freed during GC, it is put back on
  1576    string_free_list, and its `data' member and its sdata's `string'
  1577    pointer is set to null.  The size of the string is recorded in the
  1578    `n.nbytes' member of the sdata.  So, sdata structures that are no
  1579    longer used, can be easily recognized, and it's easy to compact the
  1580    sblocks of small strings which we do in compact_small_strings.  */
  1581 
  1582 /* Size in bytes of an sblock structure used for small strings.  */
  1583 
  1584 enum { SBLOCK_SIZE = MALLOC_SIZE_NEAR (8192) };
  1585 
  1586 /* Strings larger than this are considered large strings.  String data
  1587    for large strings is allocated from individual sblocks.  */
  1588 
  1589 #define LARGE_STRING_BYTES 1024
  1590 
  1591 /* The layout of a nonnull string.  */
  1592 
  1593 struct sdata
  1594 {
  1595   /* Back-pointer to the string this sdata belongs to.  If null, this
  1596      structure is free, and NBYTES (in this structure or in the union below)
  1597      contains the string's byte size (the same value that STRING_BYTES
  1598      would return if STRING were non-null).  If non-null, STRING_BYTES
  1599      (STRING) is the size of the data, and DATA contains the string's
  1600      contents.  */
  1601   struct Lisp_String *string;
  1602 
  1603 #ifdef GC_CHECK_STRING_BYTES
  1604   ptrdiff_t nbytes;
  1605 #endif
  1606 
  1607   unsigned char data[FLEXIBLE_ARRAY_MEMBER];
  1608 };
  1609 
  1610 /* A union describing string memory sub-allocated from an sblock.
  1611    This is where the contents of Lisp strings are stored.  */
  1612 
  1613 typedef union
  1614 {
  1615   struct Lisp_String *string;
  1616 
  1617   /* When STRING is nonnull, this union is actually of type 'struct sdata',
  1618      which has a flexible array member.  However, if implemented by
  1619      giving this union a member of type 'struct sdata', the union
  1620      could not be the last (flexible) member of 'struct sblock',
  1621      because C99 prohibits a flexible array member from having a type
  1622      that is itself a flexible array.  So, comment this member out here,
  1623      but remember that the option's there when using this union.  */
  1624 #if 0
  1625   struct sdata u;
  1626 #endif
  1627 
  1628   /* When STRING is null.  */
  1629   struct
  1630   {
  1631     struct Lisp_String *string;
  1632     ptrdiff_t nbytes;
  1633   } n;
  1634 } sdata;
  1635 
  1636 #define SDATA_NBYTES(S) (S)->n.nbytes
  1637 #define SDATA_DATA(S)   ((struct sdata *) (S))->data
  1638 
  1639 enum { SDATA_DATA_OFFSET = offsetof (struct sdata, data) };
  1640 
  1641 /* Structure describing a block of memory which is sub-allocated to
  1642    obtain string data memory for strings.  Blocks for small strings
  1643    are of fixed size SBLOCK_SIZE.  Blocks for large strings are made
  1644    as large as needed.  */
  1645 
  1646 struct sblock
  1647 {
  1648   /* Next in list.  */
  1649   struct sblock *next;
  1650 
  1651   /* Pointer to the next free sdata block.  This points past the end
  1652      of the sblock if there isn't any space left in this block.  */
  1653   sdata *next_free;
  1654 
  1655   /* String data.  */
  1656   sdata data[FLEXIBLE_ARRAY_MEMBER];
  1657 };
  1658 
  1659 /* Number of Lisp strings in a string_block structure.  */
  1660 
  1661 enum { STRING_BLOCK_SIZE
  1662          = ((MALLOC_SIZE_NEAR (1024) - sizeof (struct string_block *))
  1663             / sizeof (struct Lisp_String)) };
  1664 
  1665 /* Structure describing a block from which Lisp_String structures
  1666    are allocated.  */
  1667 
  1668 struct string_block
  1669 {
  1670   /* Place `strings' first, to preserve alignment.  */
  1671   struct Lisp_String strings[STRING_BLOCK_SIZE];
  1672   struct string_block *next;
  1673 };
  1674 
  1675 /* Head and tail of the list of sblock structures holding Lisp string
  1676    data.  We always allocate from current_sblock.  The NEXT pointers
  1677    in the sblock structures go from oldest_sblock to current_sblock.  */
  1678 
  1679 static struct sblock *oldest_sblock, *current_sblock;
  1680 
  1681 /* List of sblocks for large strings.  */
  1682 
  1683 static struct sblock *large_sblocks;
  1684 
  1685 /* List of string_block structures.  */
  1686 
  1687 static struct string_block *string_blocks;
  1688 
  1689 /* Free-list of Lisp_Strings.  */
  1690 
  1691 static struct Lisp_String *string_free_list;
  1692 
  1693 /* Given a pointer to a Lisp_String S which is on the free-list
  1694    string_free_list, return a pointer to its successor in the
  1695    free-list.  */
  1696 
  1697 #define NEXT_FREE_LISP_STRING(S) ((S)->u.next)
  1698 
  1699 /* Return a pointer to the sdata structure belonging to Lisp string S.
  1700    S must be live, i.e. S->data must not be null.  S->data is actually
  1701    a pointer to the `u.data' member of its sdata structure; the
  1702    structure starts at a constant offset in front of that.  */
  1703 
  1704 #define SDATA_OF_STRING(S) ((sdata *) ((S)->u.s.data - SDATA_DATA_OFFSET))
  1705 
  1706 
  1707 #ifdef GC_CHECK_STRING_OVERRUN
  1708 
  1709 /* Check for overrun in string data blocks by appending a small
  1710    "cookie" after each allocated string data block, and check for the
  1711    presence of this cookie during GC.  */
  1712 # define GC_STRING_OVERRUN_COOKIE_SIZE ROUNDUP (4, alignof (sdata))
  1713 static char const string_overrun_cookie[GC_STRING_OVERRUN_COOKIE_SIZE] =
  1714   { '\xde', '\xad', '\xbe', '\xef', /* Perhaps some zeros here.  */ };
  1715 
  1716 #else
  1717 # define GC_STRING_OVERRUN_COOKIE_SIZE 0
  1718 #endif
  1719 
  1720 /* Return the size of an sdata structure large enough to hold N bytes
  1721    of string data.  This counts the sdata structure, the N bytes, a
  1722    terminating NUL byte, and alignment padding.  */
  1723 
  1724 static ptrdiff_t
  1725 sdata_size (ptrdiff_t n)
  1726 {
  1727   /* Reserve space for the nbytes union member even when N + 1 is less
  1728      than the size of that member.  */
  1729   ptrdiff_t unaligned_size = max (SDATA_DATA_OFFSET + n + 1,
  1730                                   sizeof (sdata));
  1731   int sdata_align = max (FLEXALIGNOF (struct sdata), alignof (sdata));
  1732   return (unaligned_size + sdata_align - 1) & ~(sdata_align - 1);
  1733 }
  1734 
  1735 /* Extra bytes to allocate for each string.  */
  1736 #define GC_STRING_EXTRA GC_STRING_OVERRUN_COOKIE_SIZE
  1737 
  1738 /* Exact bound on the number of bytes in a string, not counting the
  1739    terminating null.  A string cannot contain more bytes than
  1740    STRING_BYTES_BOUND, nor can it be so long that the size_t
  1741    arithmetic in allocate_string_data would overflow while it is
  1742    calculating a value to be passed to malloc.  */
  1743 static ptrdiff_t const STRING_BYTES_MAX =
  1744   min (STRING_BYTES_BOUND,
  1745        ((SIZE_MAX
  1746          - GC_STRING_EXTRA
  1747          - offsetof (struct sblock, data)
  1748          - SDATA_DATA_OFFSET)
  1749         & ~(sizeof (EMACS_INT) - 1)));
  1750 
  1751 /* Initialize string allocation.  Called from init_alloc_once.  */
  1752 
  1753 static void
  1754 init_strings (void)
  1755 {
  1756   empty_unibyte_string = make_pure_string ("", 0, 0, 0);
  1757   staticpro (&empty_unibyte_string);
  1758   empty_multibyte_string = make_pure_string ("", 0, 0, 1);
  1759   staticpro (&empty_multibyte_string);
  1760 }
  1761 
  1762 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  1763 /* Prepare s for denoting a free sdata struct, i.e, poison all bytes
  1764    in the flexible array member, except the first SDATA_OFFSET bytes.
  1765    This is only effective for strings of size n where n > sdata_size(n).
  1766  */
  1767 # define ASAN_PREPARE_DEAD_SDATA(s, size)                          \
  1768   do {                                                             \
  1769     __asan_poison_memory_region ((s), sdata_size ((size)));        \
  1770     __asan_unpoison_memory_region (&(((s))->string),                 \
  1771                                    sizeof (struct Lisp_String *)); \
  1772     __asan_unpoison_memory_region (&SDATA_NBYTES ((s)),            \
  1773                                    sizeof (SDATA_NBYTES ((s))));   \
  1774    } while (false)
  1775 /* Prepare s for storing string data for NBYTES bytes.  */
  1776 # define ASAN_PREPARE_LIVE_SDATA(s, nbytes) \
  1777   __asan_unpoison_memory_region ((s), sdata_size ((nbytes)))
  1778 # define ASAN_POISON_SBLOCK_DATA(b, size) \
  1779   __asan_poison_memory_region ((b)->data, (size))
  1780 # define ASAN_POISON_STRING_BLOCK(b) \
  1781   __asan_poison_memory_region ((b)->strings, STRING_BLOCK_SIZE)
  1782 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_STRING_BLOCK(b) \
  1783   __asan_unpoison_memory_region ((b)->strings, STRING_BLOCK_SIZE)
  1784 # define ASAN_POISON_STRING(s) \
  1785   __asan_poison_memory_region ((s), sizeof (*(s)))
  1786 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_STRING(s) \
  1787   __asan_unpoison_memory_region ((s), sizeof (*(s)))
  1788 #else
  1789 # define ASAN_PREPARE_DEAD_SDATA(s, size) ((void) 0)
  1790 # define ASAN_PREPARE_LIVE_SDATA(s, nbytes) ((void) 0)
  1791 # define ASAN_POISON_SBLOCK_DATA(b, size) ((void) 0)
  1792 # define ASAN_POISON_STRING_BLOCK(b) ((void) 0)
  1793 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_STRING_BLOCK(b) ((void) 0)
  1794 # define ASAN_POISON_STRING(s) ((void) 0)
  1795 # define ASAN_UNPOISON_STRING(s) ((void) 0)
  1796 #endif
  1797 
  1798 #ifdef GC_CHECK_STRING_BYTES
  1799 
  1800 static int check_string_bytes_count;
  1801 
  1802 /* Like STRING_BYTES, but with debugging check.  Can be
  1803    called during GC, so pay attention to the mark bit.  */
  1804 
  1805 ptrdiff_t
  1806 string_bytes (struct Lisp_String *s)
  1807 {
  1808   ptrdiff_t nbytes =
  1809     (s->u.s.size_byte < 0 ? s->u.s.size & ~ARRAY_MARK_FLAG : s->u.s.size_byte);
  1810 
  1811   if (!PURE_P (s) && !pdumper_object_p (s) && s->u.s.data
  1812       && nbytes != SDATA_NBYTES (SDATA_OF_STRING (s)))
  1813     emacs_abort ();
  1814   return nbytes;
  1815 }
  1816 
  1817 /* Check validity of Lisp strings' string_bytes member in B.  */
  1818 
  1819 static void
  1820 check_sblock (struct sblock *b)
  1821 {
  1822   sdata *end = b->next_free;
  1823 
  1824   for (sdata *from = b->data; from < end; )
  1825     {
  1826       ptrdiff_t nbytes = sdata_size (from->string
  1827                                      ? string_bytes (from->string)
  1828                                      : SDATA_NBYTES (from));
  1829       from = (sdata *) ((char *) from + nbytes + GC_STRING_EXTRA);
  1830     }
  1831 }
  1832 
  1833 
  1834 /* Check validity of Lisp strings' string_bytes member.  ALL_P
  1835    means check all strings, otherwise check only most
  1836    recently allocated strings.  Used for hunting a bug.  */
  1837 
  1838 static void
  1839 check_string_bytes (bool all_p)
  1840 {
  1841   if (all_p)
  1842     {
  1843       struct sblock *b;
  1844 
  1845       for (b = large_sblocks; b; b = b->next)
  1846         {
  1847           struct Lisp_String *s = b->data[0].string;
  1848           if (s)
  1849             string_bytes (s);
  1850         }
  1851 
  1852       for (b = oldest_sblock; b; b = b->next)
  1853         check_sblock (b);
  1854     }
  1855   else if (current_sblock)
  1856     check_sblock (current_sblock);
  1857 }
  1858 
  1859 #else /* not GC_CHECK_STRING_BYTES */
  1860 
  1861 #define check_string_bytes(all) ((void) 0)
  1862 
  1863 #endif /* GC_CHECK_STRING_BYTES */
  1864 
  1865 #ifdef GC_CHECK_STRING_FREE_LIST
  1866 
  1867 /* Walk through the string free list looking for bogus next pointers.
  1868    This may catch buffer overrun from a previous string.  */
  1869 
  1870 static void
  1871 check_string_free_list (void)
  1872 {
  1873   struct Lisp_String *s;
  1874 
  1875   /* Pop a Lisp_String off the free-list.  */
  1876   s = string_free_list;
  1877   while (s != NULL)
  1878     {
  1879       if ((uintptr_t) s < 1024)
  1880         emacs_abort ();
  1881       s = NEXT_FREE_LISP_STRING (s);
  1882     }
  1883 }
  1884 #else
  1885 #define check_string_free_list()
  1886 #endif
  1887 
  1888 /* Return a new Lisp_String.  */
  1889 
  1890 static struct Lisp_String *
  1891 allocate_string (void)
  1892 {
  1893   struct Lisp_String *s;
  1894 
  1895   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
  1896 
  1897   /* If the free-list is empty, allocate a new string_block, and
  1898      add all the Lisp_Strings in it to the free-list.  */
  1899   if (string_free_list == NULL)
  1900     {
  1901       struct string_block *b = lisp_malloc (sizeof *b, false, MEM_TYPE_STRING);
  1902       int i;
  1903 
  1904       b->next = string_blocks;
  1905       string_blocks = b;
  1906 
  1907       for (i = STRING_BLOCK_SIZE - 1; i >= 0; --i)
  1908         {
  1909           s = b->strings + i;
  1910           /* Every string on a free list should have NULL data pointer.  */
  1911           s->u.s.data = NULL;
  1912           NEXT_FREE_LISP_STRING (s) = string_free_list;
  1913           string_free_list = s;
  1914         }
  1915       ASAN_POISON_STRING_BLOCK (b);
  1916     }
  1917 
  1918   check_string_free_list ();
  1919 
  1920   /* Pop a Lisp_String off the free-list.  */
  1921   s = string_free_list;
  1922   ASAN_UNPOISON_STRING (s);
  1923   string_free_list = NEXT_FREE_LISP_STRING (s);
  1924 
  1925   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
  1926 
  1927   ++strings_consed;
  1928   tally_consing (sizeof *s);
  1929 
  1930 #ifdef GC_CHECK_STRING_BYTES
  1931   if (!noninteractive)
  1932     {
  1933       if (++check_string_bytes_count == 200)
  1934         {
  1935           check_string_bytes_count = 0;
  1936           check_string_bytes (1);
  1937         }
  1938       else
  1939         check_string_bytes (0);
  1940     }
  1941 #endif /* GC_CHECK_STRING_BYTES */
  1942 
  1943   return s;
  1944 }
  1945 
  1946 
  1947 /* Set up Lisp_String S for holding NCHARS characters, NBYTES bytes,
  1948    plus a NUL byte at the end.  Allocate an sdata structure DATA for
  1949    S, and set S->u.s.data to SDATA->u.data.  Store a NUL byte at the
  1950    end of S->u.s.data.  Set S->u.s.size to NCHARS and S->u.s.size_byte
  1951    to NBYTES.  Free S->u.s.data if it was initially non-null.
  1952 
  1953    If CLEARIT, also clear the other bytes of S->u.s.data.  */
  1954 
  1955 static void
  1956 allocate_string_data (struct Lisp_String *s,
  1957                       EMACS_INT nchars, EMACS_INT nbytes, bool clearit,
  1958                       bool immovable)
  1959 {
  1960   sdata *data;
  1961   struct sblock *b;
  1962 
  1963   if (STRING_BYTES_MAX < nbytes)
  1964     string_overflow ();
  1965 
  1966   /* Determine the number of bytes needed to store NBYTES bytes
  1967      of string data.  */
  1968   ptrdiff_t needed = sdata_size (nbytes);
  1969 
  1970   MALLOC_BLOCK_INPUT;
  1971 
  1972   if (nbytes > LARGE_STRING_BYTES || immovable)
  1973     {
  1974       size_t size = FLEXSIZEOF (struct sblock, data, needed);
  1975 
  1976 #ifdef DOUG_LEA_MALLOC
  1977       if (!mmap_lisp_allowed_p ())
  1978         mallopt (M_MMAP_MAX, 0);
  1979 #endif
  1980 
  1981       b = lisp_malloc (size + GC_STRING_EXTRA, clearit, MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP);
  1982       ASAN_POISON_SBLOCK_DATA (b, size);
  1983 
  1984 #ifdef DOUG_LEA_MALLOC
  1985       if (!mmap_lisp_allowed_p ())
  1986         mallopt (M_MMAP_MAX, MMAP_MAX_AREAS);
  1987 #endif
  1988 
  1989       data = b->data;
  1990       b->next = large_sblocks;
  1991       b->next_free = data;
  1992       large_sblocks = b;
  1993     }
  1994   else
  1995     {
  1996       b = current_sblock;
  1997 
  1998       if (b == NULL
  1999           || (SBLOCK_SIZE - GC_STRING_EXTRA
  2000               < (char *) b->next_free - (char *) b + needed))
  2001         {
  2002           /* Not enough room in the current sblock.  */
  2003           b = lisp_malloc (SBLOCK_SIZE, false, MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP);
  2004           ASAN_POISON_SBLOCK_DATA (b, SBLOCK_SIZE);
  2005 
  2006           data = b->data;
  2007           b->next = NULL;
  2008           b->next_free = data;
  2009 
  2010           if (current_sblock)
  2011             current_sblock->next = b;
  2012           else
  2013             oldest_sblock = b;
  2014           current_sblock = b;
  2015         }
  2016 
  2017       data = b->next_free;
  2018 
  2019       if (clearit)
  2020         {
  2021 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  2022           /* We are accessing SDATA_DATA (data) before it gets
  2023            * normally unpoisoned, so do it manually.  */
  2024           __asan_unpoison_memory_region (SDATA_DATA (data), nbytes);
  2025 #endif
  2026           memset (SDATA_DATA (data), 0, nbytes);
  2027         }
  2028     }
  2029 
  2030   ASAN_PREPARE_LIVE_SDATA (data, nbytes);
  2031   data->string = s;
  2032   b->next_free = (sdata *) ((char *) data + needed + GC_STRING_EXTRA);
  2033   eassert ((uintptr_t) b->next_free % alignof (sdata) == 0);
  2034 
  2035   MALLOC_UNBLOCK_INPUT;
  2036 
  2037   s->u.s.data = SDATA_DATA (data);
  2038 #ifdef GC_CHECK_STRING_BYTES
  2039   SDATA_NBYTES (data) = nbytes;
  2040 #endif
  2041   s->u.s.size = nchars;
  2042   s->u.s.size_byte = nbytes;
  2043   s->u.s.data[nbytes] = '\0';
  2044 #ifdef GC_CHECK_STRING_OVERRUN
  2045   memcpy ((char *) data + needed, string_overrun_cookie,
  2046           GC_STRING_OVERRUN_COOKIE_SIZE);
  2047 #endif
  2048 
  2049   tally_consing (needed);
  2050 }
  2051 
  2052 /* Reallocate multibyte STRING data when a single character is replaced.
  2053    The character is at byte offset CIDX_BYTE in the string.
  2054    The character being replaced is CLEN bytes long,
  2055    and the character that will replace it is NEW_CLEN bytes long.
  2056    Return the address where the caller should store the new character.  */
  2057 
  2058 unsigned char *
  2059 resize_string_data (Lisp_Object string, ptrdiff_t cidx_byte,
  2060                     int clen, int new_clen)
  2061 {
  2062   eassume (STRING_MULTIBYTE (string));
  2063   sdata *old_sdata = SDATA_OF_STRING (XSTRING (string));
  2064   ptrdiff_t nchars = SCHARS (string);
  2065   ptrdiff_t nbytes = SBYTES (string);
  2066   ptrdiff_t new_nbytes = nbytes + (new_clen - clen);
  2067   unsigned char *data = SDATA (string);
  2068   unsigned char *new_charaddr;
  2069 
  2070   if (sdata_size (nbytes) == sdata_size (new_nbytes))
  2071     {
  2072       /* No need to reallocate, as the size change falls within the
  2073          alignment slop.  */
  2074       XSTRING (string)->u.s.size_byte = new_nbytes;
  2075 #ifdef GC_CHECK_STRING_BYTES
  2076       SDATA_NBYTES (old_sdata) = new_nbytes;
  2077 #endif
  2078       new_charaddr = data + cidx_byte;
  2079       memmove (new_charaddr + new_clen, new_charaddr + clen,
  2080                nbytes - (cidx_byte + (clen - 1)));
  2081     }
  2082   else
  2083     {
  2084       allocate_string_data (XSTRING (string), nchars, new_nbytes, false, false);
  2085       unsigned char *new_data = SDATA (string);
  2086       new_charaddr = new_data + cidx_byte;
  2087       memcpy (new_charaddr + new_clen, data + cidx_byte + clen,
  2088               nbytes - (cidx_byte + clen));
  2089       memcpy (new_data, data, cidx_byte);
  2090 
  2091       /* Mark old string data as free by setting its string back-pointer
  2092          to null, and record the size of the data in it.  */
  2093       SDATA_NBYTES (old_sdata) = nbytes;
  2094       old_sdata->string = NULL;
  2095     }
  2096 
  2097   clear_string_char_byte_cache ();
  2098 
  2099   return new_charaddr;
  2100 }
  2101 
  2102 
  2103 /* Sweep and compact strings.  */
  2104 
  2105 NO_INLINE /* For better stack traces */
  2106 static void
  2107 sweep_strings (void)
  2108 {
  2109   struct string_block *b, *next;
  2110   struct string_block *live_blocks = NULL;
  2111 
  2112   string_free_list = NULL;
  2113   gcstat.total_strings = gcstat.total_free_strings = 0;
  2114   gcstat.total_string_bytes = 0;
  2115 
  2116   /* Scan strings_blocks, free Lisp_Strings that aren't marked.  */
  2117   for (b = string_blocks; b; b = next)
  2118     {
  2119       int i, nfree = 0;
  2120       struct Lisp_String *free_list_before = string_free_list;
  2121 
  2122       ASAN_UNPOISON_STRING_BLOCK (b);
  2123 
  2124       next = b->next;
  2125 
  2126       for (i = 0; i < STRING_BLOCK_SIZE; ++i)
  2127         {
  2128           struct Lisp_String *s = b->strings + i;
  2129 
  2130           ASAN_UNPOISON_STRING (s);
  2131 
  2132           if (s->u.s.data)
  2133             {
  2134               /* String was not on free-list before.  */
  2135               if (XSTRING_MARKED_P (s))
  2136                 {
  2137                   /* String is live; unmark it and its intervals.  */
  2138                   XUNMARK_STRING (s);
  2139 
  2140                   /* Do not use string_(set|get)_intervals here.  */
  2141                   s->u.s.intervals = balance_intervals (s->u.s.intervals);
  2142 
  2143                   gcstat.total_strings++;
  2144                   gcstat.total_string_bytes += STRING_BYTES (s);
  2145                 }
  2146               else
  2147                 {
  2148                   /* String is dead.  Put it on the free-list.  */
  2149                   sdata *data = SDATA_OF_STRING (s);
  2150 
  2151                   /* Save the size of S in its sdata so that we know
  2152                      how large that is.  Reset the sdata's string
  2153                      back-pointer so that we know it's free.  */
  2154 #ifdef GC_CHECK_STRING_BYTES
  2155                   if (string_bytes (s) != SDATA_NBYTES (data))
  2156                     emacs_abort ();
  2157 #else
  2158                   data->n.nbytes = STRING_BYTES (s);
  2159 #endif
  2160                   data->string = NULL;
  2161 
  2162                   /* Reset the strings's `data' member so that we
  2163                      know it's free.  */
  2164                   s->u.s.data = NULL;
  2165 
  2166                   /* Put the string on the free-list.  */
  2167                   NEXT_FREE_LISP_STRING (s) = string_free_list;
  2168                   ASAN_POISON_STRING (s);
  2169                   ASAN_PREPARE_DEAD_SDATA (data, SDATA_NBYTES (data));
  2170                   string_free_list = s;
  2171                   ++nfree;
  2172                 }
  2173             }
  2174           else
  2175             {
  2176               /* S was on the free-list before.  Put it there again.  */
  2177               NEXT_FREE_LISP_STRING (s) = string_free_list;
  2178               ASAN_POISON_STRING (s);
  2179 
  2180               string_free_list = s;
  2181               ++nfree;
  2182             }
  2183         }
  2184 
  2185       /* Free blocks that contain free Lisp_Strings only, except
  2186          the first two of them.  */
  2187       if (nfree == STRING_BLOCK_SIZE
  2188           && gcstat.total_free_strings > STRING_BLOCK_SIZE)
  2189         {
  2190           lisp_free (b);
  2191           string_free_list = free_list_before;
  2192         }
  2193       else
  2194         {
  2195           gcstat.total_free_strings += nfree;
  2196           b->next = live_blocks;
  2197           live_blocks = b;
  2198         }
  2199     }
  2200 
  2201   check_string_free_list ();
  2202 
  2203   string_blocks = live_blocks;
  2204   free_large_strings ();
  2205   compact_small_strings ();
  2206 
  2207   check_string_free_list ();
  2208 }
  2209 
  2210 
  2211 /* Free dead large strings.  */
  2212 
  2213 static void
  2214 free_large_strings (void)
  2215 {
  2216   struct sblock *b, *next;
  2217   struct sblock *live_blocks = NULL;
  2218 
  2219   for (b = large_sblocks; b; b = next)
  2220     {
  2221       next = b->next;
  2222 
  2223       if (b->data[0].string == NULL)
  2224         lisp_free (b);
  2225       else
  2226         {
  2227           b->next = live_blocks;
  2228           live_blocks = b;
  2229         }
  2230     }
  2231 
  2232   large_sblocks = live_blocks;
  2233 }
  2234 
  2235 
  2236 /* Compact data of small strings.  Free sblocks that don't contain
  2237    data of live strings after compaction.  */
  2238 
  2239 static void
  2240 compact_small_strings (void)
  2241 {
