  4364     spare_memory[5] = lisp_malloc (sizeof (struct string_block),
  4365                                    false, MEM_TYPE_SPARE);
  4366   if (spare_memory[6] == 0)
  4367     spare_memory[6] = lisp_malloc (sizeof (struct string_block),
  4368                                    false, MEM_TYPE_SPARE);
  4369   if (spare_memory[0] && spare_memory[1] && spare_memory[5])
  4370     Vmemory_full = Qnil;
  4371 #endif
  4372 }
  4373 
  4374 /************************************************************************
  4375                            C Stack Marking
  4376  ************************************************************************/
  4377 
  4378 /* Conservative C stack marking requires a method to identify possibly
  4379    live Lisp objects given a pointer value.  We do this by keeping
  4380    track of blocks of Lisp data that are allocated in a red-black tree
  4381    (see also the comment of mem_node which is the type of nodes in
  4382    that tree).  Function lisp_malloc adds information for an allocated
  4383    block to the red-black tree with calls to mem_insert, and function
  4384    lisp_free removes it with mem_delete.  Functions live_string_p etc
  4385    call mem_find to lookup information about a given pointer in the
  4386    tree, and use that to determine if the pointer points into a Lisp
  4387    object or not.  */
  4388 
  4389 /* Initialize this part of alloc.c.  */
  4390 
  4391 static void
  4392 mem_init (void)
  4393 {
  4394   mem_z.left = mem_z.right = MEM_NIL;
  4395   mem_z.parent = NULL;
  4396   mem_z.color = MEM_BLACK;
  4397   mem_z.start = mem_z.end = NULL;
  4398   mem_root = MEM_NIL;
  4399 }
  4400 
  4401 
  4402 /* Value is a pointer to the mem_node containing START.  Value is
  4403    MEM_NIL if there is no node in the tree containing START.  */
  4404 
  4405 static struct mem_node *
  4406 mem_find (void *start)
  4407 {
  4408   struct mem_node *p;
  4409 
  4410   if (start < min_heap_address || start > max_heap_address)
  4411     return MEM_NIL;
  4412 
  4413   /* Make the search always successful to speed up the loop below.  */
  4414   mem_z.start = start;
  4415   mem_z.end = (char *) start + 1;
  4416 
  4417   p = mem_root;
  4418   while (start < p->start || start >= p->end)
  4419     p = start < p->start ? p->left : p->right;
  4420   return p;
  4421 }
  4422 
  4423 
  4424 /* Insert a new node into the tree for a block of memory with start
  4425    address START, end address END, and type TYPE.  Value is a
  4426    pointer to the node that was inserted.  */
  4427 
  4428 static struct mem_node *
  4429 mem_insert (void *start, void *end, enum mem_type type)
  4430 {
  4431   struct mem_node *c, *parent, *x;
  4432 
  4433   if (min_heap_address == NULL || start < min_heap_address)
  4434     min_heap_address = start;
  4435   if (max_heap_address == NULL || end > max_heap_address)
  4436     max_heap_address = end;
  4437 
  4438   /* See where in the tree a node for START belongs.  In this
  4439      particular application, it shouldn't happen that a node is already
  4440      present.  For debugging purposes, let's check that.  */
  4441   c = mem_root;
  4442   parent = NULL;
  4443 
  4444   while (c != MEM_NIL)
  4445     {
  4446       parent = c;
  4447       c = start < c->start ? c->left : c->right;
  4448     }
  4449 
  4450   /* Create a new node.  */
  4451 #ifdef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
  4452   x = malloc (sizeof *x);
  4453   if (x == NULL)
  4454     emacs_abort ();
  4455 #else
  4456   x = xmalloc (sizeof *x);
  4457 #endif
  4458   x->start = start;
  4459   x->end = end;
  4460   x->type = type;
  4461   x->parent = parent;
  4462   x->left = x->right = MEM_NIL;
  4463   x->color = MEM_RED;
  4464 
  4465   /* Insert it as child of PARENT or install it as root.  */
  4466   if (parent)
  4467     {
  4468       if (start < parent->start)
  4469         parent->left = x;
  4470       else
  4471         parent->right = x;
  4472     }
  4473   else
  4474     mem_root = x;
  4475 
  4476   /* Re-establish red-black tree properties.  */
  4477   mem_insert_fixup (x);
  4478 
  4479   return x;
  4480 }
  4481 
  4482 
  4483 /* Re-establish the red-black properties of the tree, and thereby
  4484    balance the tree, after node X has been inserted; X is always red.  */
  4485 
  4486 static void
  4487 mem_insert_fixup (struct mem_node *x)
  4488 {
  4489   while (x != mem_root && x->parent->color == MEM_RED)
  4490     {
  4491       /* X is red and its parent is red.  This is a violation of
  4492          red-black tree property #3.  */
  4493 
  4494       if (x->parent == x->parent->parent->left)
  4495         {
  4496           /* We're on the left side of our grandparent, and Y is our
  4497              "uncle".  */
  4498           struct mem_node *y = x->parent->parent->right;
  4499 
  4500           if (y->color == MEM_RED)
  4501             {
  4502               /* Uncle and parent are red but should be black because
  4503                  X is red.  Change the colors accordingly and proceed
  4504                  with the grandparent.  */
  4505               x->parent->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4506               y->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4507               x->parent->parent->color = MEM_RED;
  4508               x = x->parent->parent;
  4509             }
  4510           else
  4511             {
  4512               /* Parent and uncle have different colors; parent is
  4513                  red, uncle is black.  */
  4514               if (x == x->parent->right)
  4515                 {
  4516                   x = x->parent;
  4517                   mem_rotate_left (x);
  4518                 }
  4519 
  4520               x->parent->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4521               x->parent->parent->color = MEM_RED;
  4522               mem_rotate_right (x->parent->parent);
  4523             }
  4524         }
  4525       else
  4526         {
  4527           /* This is the symmetrical case of above.  */
  4528           struct mem_node *y = x->parent->parent->left;
  4529 
  4530           if (y->color == MEM_RED)
  4531             {
  4532               x->parent->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4533               y->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4534               x->parent->parent->color = MEM_RED;
  4535               x = x->parent->parent;
  4536             }
  4537           else
  4538             {
  4539               if (x == x->parent->left)
  4540                 {
  4541                   x = x->parent;
  4542                   mem_rotate_right (x);
  4543                 }
  4544 
  4545               x->parent->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4546               x->parent->parent->color = MEM_RED;
  4547               mem_rotate_left (x->parent->parent);
  4548             }
  4549         }
  4550     }
  4551 
  4552   /* The root may have been changed to red due to the algorithm.  Set
  4553      it to black so that property #5 is satisfied.  */
  4554   mem_root->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4555 }
  4556 
  4557 
  4558 /*   (x)                   (y)
  4559      / \                   / \
  4560     a   (y)      ===>    (x)  c
  4561         / \              / \
  4562        b   c            a   b  */
  4563 
  4564 static void
  4565 mem_rotate_left (struct mem_node *x)
  4566 {
  4567   struct mem_node *y;
  4568 
  4569   /* Turn y's left sub-tree into x's right sub-tree.  */
  4570   y = x->right;
  4571   x->right = y->left;
  4572   if (y->left != MEM_NIL)
  4573     y->left->parent = x;
  4574 
  4575   /* Y's parent was x's parent.  */
  4576   if (y != MEM_NIL)
  4577     y->parent = x->parent;
  4578 
  4579   /* Get the parent to point to y instead of x.  */
  4580   if (x->parent)
  4581     {
  4582       if (x == x->parent->left)
  4583         x->parent->left = y;
  4584       else
  4585         x->parent->right = y;
  4586     }
  4587   else
  4588     mem_root = y;
  4589 
  4590   /* Put x on y's left.  */
  4591   y->left = x;
  4592   if (x != MEM_NIL)
  4593     x->parent = y;
  4594 }
  4595 
  4596 
  4597 /*     (x)                (Y)
  4598        / \                / \
  4599      (y)  c      ===>    a  (x)
  4600      / \                    / \
  4601     a   b                  b   c  */
  4602 
  4603 static void
  4604 mem_rotate_right (struct mem_node *x)
  4605 {
  4606   struct mem_node *y = x->left;
  4607 
  4608   x->left = y->right;
  4609   if (y->right != MEM_NIL)
  4610     y->right->parent = x;
  4611 
  4612   if (y != MEM_NIL)
  4613     y->parent = x->parent;
  4614   if (x->parent)
  4615     {
  4616       if (x == x->parent->right)
  4617         x->parent->right = y;
  4618       else
  4619         x->parent->left = y;
  4620     }
  4621   else
  4622     mem_root = y;
  4623 
  4624   y->right = x;
  4625   if (x != MEM_NIL)
  4626     x->parent = y;
  4627 }
  4628 
  4629 
  4630 /* Delete node Z from the tree.  If Z is null or MEM_NIL, do nothing.  */
  4631 
  4632 static void
  4633 mem_delete (struct mem_node *z)
  4634 {
  4635   struct mem_node *x, *y;
  4636 
  4637   if (!z || z == MEM_NIL)
  4638     return;
  4639 
  4640   if (z->left == MEM_NIL || z->right == MEM_NIL)
  4641     y = z;
  4642   else
  4643     {
  4644       y = z->right;
  4645       while (y->left != MEM_NIL)
  4646         y = y->left;
  4647     }
  4648 
  4649   if (y->left != MEM_NIL)
  4650     x = y->left;
  4651   else
  4652     x = y->right;
  4653 
  4654   x->parent = y->parent;
  4655   if (y->parent)
  4656     {
  4657       if (y == y->parent->left)
  4658         y->parent->left = x;
  4659       else
  4660         y->parent->right = x;
  4661     }
  4662   else
  4663     mem_root = x;
  4664 
  4665   if (y != z)
  4666     {
  4667       z->start = y->start;
  4668       z->end = y->end;
  4669       z->type = y->type;
  4670     }
  4671 
  4672   if (y->color == MEM_BLACK)
  4673     mem_delete_fixup (x);
  4674 
  4675 #ifdef GC_MALLOC_CHECK
  4676   free (y);
  4677 #else
  4678   xfree (y);
  4679 #endif
  4680 }
  4681 
  4682 
  4683 /* Re-establish the red-black properties of the tree, after a
  4684    deletion.  */
  4685 
  4686 static void
  4687 mem_delete_fixup (struct mem_node *x)
  4688 {
  4689   while (x != mem_root && x->color == MEM_BLACK)
  4690     {
  4691       if (x == x->parent->left)
  4692         {
  4693           struct mem_node *w = x->parent->right;
  4694 
  4695           if (w->color == MEM_RED)
  4696             {
  4697               w->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4698               x->parent->color = MEM_RED;
  4699               mem_rotate_left (x->parent);
  4700               w = x->parent->right;
  4701             }
  4702 
  4703           if (w->left->color == MEM_BLACK && w->right->color == MEM_BLACK)
  4704             {
  4705               w->color = MEM_RED;
  4706               x = x->parent;
  4707             }
  4708           else
  4709             {
  4710               if (w->right->color == MEM_BLACK)
  4711                 {
  4712                   w->left->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4713                   w->color = MEM_RED;
  4714                   mem_rotate_right (w);
  4715                   w = x->parent->right;
  4716                 }
  4717               w->color = x->parent->color;
  4718               x->parent->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4719               w->right->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4720               mem_rotate_left (x->parent);
  4721               x = mem_root;
  4722             }
  4723         }
  4724       else
  4725         {
  4726           struct mem_node *w = x->parent->left;
  4727 
  4728           if (w->color == MEM_RED)
  4729             {
  4730               w->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4731               x->parent->color = MEM_RED;
  4732               mem_rotate_right (x->parent);
  4733               w = x->parent->left;
  4734             }
  4735 
  4736           if (w->right->color == MEM_BLACK && w->left->color == MEM_BLACK)
  4737             {
  4738               w->color = MEM_RED;
  4739               x = x->parent;
  4740             }
  4741           else
  4742             {
  4743               if (w->left->color == MEM_BLACK)
  4744                 {
  4745                   w->right->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4746                   w->color = MEM_RED;
  4747                   mem_rotate_left (w);
  4748                   w = x->parent->left;
  4749                 }
  4750 
  4751               w->color = x->parent->color;
  4752               x->parent->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4753               w->left->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4754               mem_rotate_right (x->parent);
  4755               x = mem_root;
  4756             }
  4757         }
  4758     }
  4759 
  4760   x->color = MEM_BLACK;
  4761 }
  4762 
  4763 
  4764 /* If P is a pointer into a live Lisp string object on the heap,
  4765    return the object's address.  Otherwise, return NULL.  M points to the
  4766    mem_block for P.
  4767 
  4768    This and other *_holding functions look for a pointer anywhere into
  4769    the object, not merely for a pointer to the start of the object,
  4770    because some compilers sometimes optimize away the latter.  See
  4771    Bug#28213.  */
  4772 
  4773 static struct Lisp_String *
  4774 live_string_holding (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  4775 {
  4776   eassert (m->type == MEM_TYPE_STRING);
  4777 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  4778   if (__asan_address_is_poisoned (p))
  4779     return NULL;
  4780 #endif
  4781 
  4782   struct string_block *b = m->start;
  4783   char *cp = p;
  4784   ptrdiff_t offset = cp - (char *) &b->strings[0];
  4785 
  4786   /* P must point into a Lisp_String structure, and it
  4787      must not be on the free-list.  */
  4788   if (0 <= offset && offset < sizeof b->strings)
  4789     {
  4790       ptrdiff_t off = offset % sizeof b->strings[0];
  4791       if (off == Lisp_String
  4792           || off == 0
  4793           || off == offsetof (struct Lisp_String, u.s.size_byte)
  4794           || off == offsetof (struct Lisp_String, u.s.intervals)
  4795           || off == offsetof (struct Lisp_String, u.s.data))
  4796         {
  4797           struct Lisp_String *s = p = cp -= off;
  4798 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  4799           if (__asan_region_is_poisoned (s, sizeof (*s)))
  4800             return NULL;
  4801 #endif
  4802           if (s->u.s.data)
  4803             return s;
  4804         }
  4805     }
  4806   return NULL;
  4807 }
  4808 
  4809 static bool
  4810 live_string_p (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  4811 {
  4812   return live_string_holding (m, p) == p;
  4813 }
  4814 
  4815 /* If P is a pointer into a live Lisp cons object on the heap, return
  4816    the object's address.  Otherwise, return NULL.  M points to the
  4817    mem_block for P.  */
  4818 
  4819 static struct Lisp_Cons *
  4820 live_cons_holding (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  4821 {
  4822   eassert (m->type == MEM_TYPE_CONS);
  4823 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  4824   if (__asan_address_is_poisoned (p))
  4825     return NULL;
  4826 #endif
  4827 
  4828   struct cons_block *b = m->start;
  4829   char *cp = p;
  4830   ptrdiff_t offset = cp - (char *) &b->conses[0];
  4831 
  4832   /* P must point into a Lisp_Cons, not be
  4833      one of the unused cells in the current cons block,
  4834      and not be on the free-list.  */
  4835   if (0 <= offset && offset < sizeof b->conses
  4836       && (b != cons_block
  4837           || offset / sizeof b->conses[0] < cons_block_index))
  4838     {
  4839       ptrdiff_t off = offset % sizeof b->conses[0];
  4840       if (off == Lisp_Cons
  4841           || off == 0
  4842           || off == offsetof (struct Lisp_Cons, u.s.u.cdr))
  4843         {
  4844           struct Lisp_Cons *s = p = cp -= off;
  4845 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  4846           if (__asan_region_is_poisoned (s, sizeof (*s)))
  4847             return NULL;
  4848 #endif
  4849           if (!deadp (s->u.s.car))
  4850             return s;
  4851         }
  4852     }
  4853   return NULL;
  4854 }
  4855 
  4856 static bool
  4857 live_cons_p (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  4858 {
  4859   return live_cons_holding (m, p) == p;
  4860 }
  4861 
  4862 
  4863 /* If P is a pointer into a live Lisp symbol object on the heap,
  4864    return the object's address.  Otherwise, return NULL.  M points to the
  4865    mem_block for P.  */
  4866 
  4867 static struct Lisp_Symbol *
  4868 live_symbol_holding (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  4869 {
  4870   eassert (m->type == MEM_TYPE_SYMBOL);
  4871 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  4872   if (__asan_address_is_poisoned (p))
  4873     return NULL;
  4874 #endif
  4875   struct symbol_block *b = m->start;
  4876   char *cp = p;
  4877   ptrdiff_t offset = cp - (char *) &b->symbols[0];
  4878 
  4879   /* P must point into the Lisp_Symbol, not be
  4880      one of the unused cells in the current symbol block,
  4881      and not be on the free-list.  */
  4882   if (0 <= offset && offset < sizeof b->symbols
  4883       && (b != symbol_block
  4884           || offset / sizeof b->symbols[0] < symbol_block_index))
  4885     {
  4886       ptrdiff_t off = offset % sizeof b->symbols[0];
  4887       if (off == Lisp_Symbol
  4888 
  4889           /* Plain '|| off == 0' would run afoul of GCC 10.2
  4890              -Wlogical-op, as Lisp_Symbol happens to be zero.  */
  4891           || (Lisp_Symbol != 0 && off == 0)
  4892 
  4893           || off == offsetof (struct Lisp_Symbol, u.s.name)
  4894           || off == offsetof (struct Lisp_Symbol, u.s.val)
  4895           || off == offsetof (struct Lisp_Symbol, u.s.function)
  4896           || off == offsetof (struct Lisp_Symbol, u.s.plist)
  4897           || off == offsetof (struct Lisp_Symbol, u.s.next))
  4898         {
  4899           struct Lisp_Symbol *s = p = cp -= off;
  4900 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  4901           if (__asan_region_is_poisoned (s, sizeof (*s)))
  4902             return NULL;
  4903 #endif
  4904           if (!deadp (s->u.s.function))
  4905             return s;
  4906         }
  4907     }
  4908   return NULL;
  4909 }
  4910 
  4911 static bool
  4912 live_symbol_p (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  4913 {
  4914   return live_symbol_holding (m, p) == p;
  4915 }
  4916 
  4917 
  4918 /* If P is a (possibly-tagged) pointer to a live Lisp_Float on the
  4919    heap, return the address of the Lisp_Float.  Otherwise, return NULL.
  4920    M is a pointer to the mem_block for P.  */
  4921 
  4922 static struct Lisp_Float *
  4923 live_float_holding (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  4924 {
  4925   eassert (m->type == MEM_TYPE_FLOAT);
  4926 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  4927   if (__asan_address_is_poisoned (p))
  4928     return NULL;
  4929 #endif
  4930 
  4931   struct float_block *b = m->start;
  4932   char *cp = p;
  4933   ptrdiff_t offset = cp - (char *) &b->floats[0];
  4934 
  4935   /* P must point to (or be a tagged pointer to) the start of a
  4936      Lisp_Float and not be one of the unused cells in the current
  4937      float block.  */
  4938   if (0 <= offset && offset < sizeof b->floats)
  4939     {
  4940       int off = offset % sizeof b->floats[0];
  4941       if ((off == Lisp_Float || off == 0)
  4942           && (b != float_block
  4943               || offset / sizeof b->floats[0] < float_block_index))
  4944         {
  4945           struct Lisp_Float *f = (struct Lisp_Float *) (cp - off);
  4946 #if GC_ASAN_POISON_OBJECTS
  4947           if (__asan_region_is_poisoned (f, sizeof (*f)))
  4948             return NULL;
  4949 #endif
  4950           return f;
  4951         }
  4952     }
  4953   return NULL;
  4954 }
  4955 
  4956 static bool
  4957 live_float_p (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  4958 {
  4959   return live_float_holding (m, p) == p;
  4960 }
  4961 
  4962 /* Return VECTOR if P points within it, NULL otherwise.  */
  4963 
  4964 static struct Lisp_Vector *
  4965 live_vector_pointer (struct Lisp_Vector *vector, void *p)
  4966 {
  4967   void *vvector = vector;
  4968   char *cvector = vvector;
  4969   char *cp = p;
  4970   ptrdiff_t offset = cp - cvector;
  4971   return ((offset == Lisp_Vectorlike
  4972            || offset == 0
  4973            || (sizeof vector->header <= offset
  4974                && offset < vector_nbytes (vector)
  4975                && (! (vector->header.size & PSEUDOVECTOR_FLAG)
  4976                    ? (offsetof (struct Lisp_Vector, contents) <= offset
  4977                       && (((offset - offsetof (struct Lisp_Vector, contents))
  4978                            % word_size)
  4979                           == 0))
  4980                    /* For non-bool-vector pseudovectors, treat any pointer
  4981                       past the header as valid since it's too much of a pain
  4982                       to write special-case code for every pseudovector.  */
  4983                    : (! PSEUDOVECTOR_TYPEP (&vector->header, PVEC_BOOL_VECTOR)
  4984                       || offset == offsetof (struct Lisp_Bool_Vector, size)
  4985                       || (offsetof (struct Lisp_Bool_Vector, data) <= offset
  4986                           && (((offset
  4987                                 - offsetof (struct Lisp_Bool_Vector, data))
  4988                                % sizeof (bits_word))
  4989                               == 0))))))
  4990           ? vector : NULL);
  4991 }
  4992 
  4993 /* If P is a pointer to a live, large vector-like object, return the object.
  4994    Otherwise, return nil.
  4995    M is a pointer to the mem_block for P.  */
  4996 
  4997 static struct Lisp_Vector *
  4998 live_large_vector_holding (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  4999 {
  5000   eassert (m->type == MEM_TYPE_VECTORLIKE);
  5001   return live_vector_pointer (large_vector_vec (m->start), p);
  5002 }
  5003 
  5004 static bool
  5005 live_large_vector_p (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  5006 {
  5007   return live_large_vector_holding (m, p) == p;
  5008 }
  5009 
  5010 /* If P is a pointer to a live, small vector-like object, return the object.
  5011    Otherwise, return NULL.
  5012    M is a pointer to the mem_block for P.  */
  5013 
  5014 static struct Lisp_Vector *
  5015 live_small_vector_holding (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  5016 {
  5017   eassert (m->type == MEM_TYPE_VECTOR_BLOCK);
  5018   struct Lisp_Vector *vp = p;
  5019   struct vector_block *block = m->start;
  5020   struct Lisp_Vector *vector = (struct Lisp_Vector *) block->data;
  5021 
  5022   /* P is in the block's allocation range.  Scan the block
  5023      up to P and see whether P points to the start of some
  5024      vector which is not on a free list.  FIXME: check whether
  5025      some allocation patterns (probably a lot of short vectors)
  5026      may cause a substantial overhead of this loop.  */
  5027   while (VECTOR_IN_BLOCK (vector, block) && vector <= vp)
  5028     {
  5029       struct Lisp_Vector *next = ADVANCE (vector, vector_nbytes (vector));
  5030       if (vp < next && !PSEUDOVECTOR_TYPEP (&vector->header, PVEC_FREE))
  5031         return live_vector_pointer (vector, vp);
  5032       vector = next;
  5033     }
  5034   return NULL;
  5035 }
  5036 
  5037 static bool
  5038 live_small_vector_p (struct mem_node *m, void *p)
  5039 {
  5040   return live_small_vector_holding (m, p) == p;
  5041 }
  5042 
  5043 /* If P points to Lisp data, mark that as live if it isn't already
  5044    marked.  */
  5045 
  5046 static void
  5047 mark_maybe_pointer (void *p, bool symbol_only)
  5048 {
  5049   struct mem_node *m;
  5050 
  5051 #if USE_VALGRIND
  5052   VALGRIND_MAKE_MEM_DEFINED (&p, sizeof (p));
  5053 #endif
  5054 
  5055   /* If the pointer is in the dump image and the dump has a record
  5056      of the object starting at the place where the pointer points, we
  5057      definitely have an object.  If the pointer is in the dump image
  5058      and the dump has no idea what the pointer is pointing at, we
  5059      definitely _don't_ have an object.  */
  5060   if (pdumper_object_p (p))
  5061     {
  5062       /* FIXME: This code assumes that every reachable pdumper object
  5063          is addressed either by a pointer to the object start, or by
  5064          the same pointer with an LSB-style tag.  This assumption
  5065          fails if a pdumper object is reachable only via machine
  5066          addresses of non-initial object components.  Although such
  5067          addressing is rare in machine code generated by C compilers
  5068          from Emacs source code, it can occur in some cases.  To fix
  5069          this problem, the pdumper code should grok non-initial
  5070          addresses, as the non-pdumper code does.  */
  5071       uintptr_t mask = VALMASK & UINTPTR_MAX;
  5072       uintptr_t masked_p = (uintptr_t) p & mask;
  5073       void *po = (void *) masked_p;
  5074       char *cp = p;
  5075       char *cpo = po;
  5076       /* Don't use pdumper_object_p_precise here! It doesn't check the
  5077          tag bits. OBJ here might be complete garbage, so we need to
  5078          verify both the pointer and the tag.  */
  5079       int type = pdumper_find_object_type (po);
  5080       if (pdumper_valid_object_type_p (type)
  5081           && (!USE_LSB_TAG || p == po || cp - cpo == type))
  5082         {
  5083           if (type == Lisp_Symbol)
  5084             mark_object (make_lisp_symbol (po));
  5085           else if (!symbol_only)
  5086             mark_object (make_lisp_ptr (po, type));
  5087         }
  5088       return;
  5089     }
  5090 
  5091   m = mem_find (p);
  5092   if (m != MEM_NIL)
  5093     {
  5094       Lisp_Object obj;
  5095 
  5096       switch (m->type)
  5097         {
  5098         case MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP:
  5099         case MEM_TYPE_SPARE:
  5100           /* Nothing to do; not a pointer to Lisp memory.  */
  5101           return;
  5102 
  5103         case MEM_TYPE_CONS:
  5104           {
  5105             if (symbol_only)
  5106               return;
  5107             struct Lisp_Cons *h = live_cons_holding (m, p);
  5108             if (!h)
  5109               return;
  5110             obj = make_lisp_ptr (h, Lisp_Cons);
  5111           }
  5112           break;
  5113 
  5114         case MEM_TYPE_STRING:
  5115           {
  5116             if (symbol_only)
  5117               return;
  5118             struct Lisp_String *h = live_string_holding (m, p);
  5119             if (!h)
  5120               return;
  5121             obj = make_lisp_ptr (h, Lisp_String);
  5122           }
  5123           break;
  5124 
  5125         case MEM_TYPE_SYMBOL:
  5126           {
  5127             struct Lisp_Symbol *h = live_symbol_holding (m, p);
  5128             if (!h)
  5129               return;
  5130             obj = make_lisp_symbol (h);
  5131           }
  5132           break;
  5133 
  5134         case MEM_TYPE_FLOAT:
  5135           {
  5136             if (symbol_only)
  5137               return;
  5138             struct Lisp_Float *h = live_float_holding (m, p);
  5139             if (!h)
  5140               return;
  5141             obj = make_lisp_ptr (h, Lisp_Float);
  5142           }
  5143           break;
  5144 
  5145         case MEM_TYPE_VECTORLIKE:
  5146           {
  5147             if (symbol_only)
  5148               return;
  5149             struct Lisp_Vector *h = live_large_vector_holding (m, p);
  5150             if (!h)
  5151               return;
  5152             obj = make_lisp_ptr (h, Lisp_Vectorlike);
  5153           }
  5154           break;
  5155 
  5156         case MEM_TYPE_VECTOR_BLOCK:
  5157           {
  5158             if (symbol_only)
  5159               return;
  5160             struct Lisp_Vector *h = live_small_vector_holding (m, p);
  5161             if (!h)
  5162               return;
  5163             obj = make_lisp_ptr (h, Lisp_Vectorlike);
  5164           }
  5165           break;
  5166 
  5167         default:
  5168           emacs_abort ();
  5169         }
  5170 
  5171       mark_object (obj);
  5172     }
  5173 }
  5174 
  5175 
  5176 /* Alignment of pointer values.  Use alignof, as it sometimes returns
  5177    a smaller alignment than GCC's __alignof__ and mark_memory might
  5178    miss objects if __alignof__ were used.  */
  5179 #define GC_POINTER_ALIGNMENT alignof (void *)
  5180 
  5181 /* Mark Lisp objects referenced from the address range START..END
  5182    or END..START.  */
  5183 
  5184 void ATTRIBUTE_NO_SANITIZE_ADDRESS
  5185 mark_memory (void const *start, void const *end)
  5186 {
  5187   char const *pp;
  5188 
  5189   /* Make START the pointer to the start of the memory region,
  5190      if it isn't already.  */
  5191   if (end < start)
  5192     {
  5193       void const *tem = start;
  5194       start = end;
  5195       end = tem;
  5196     }
  5197 
  5198   eassert (((uintptr_t) start) % GC_POINTER_ALIGNMENT == 0);
  5199 
  5200   /* Mark Lisp data pointed to.  This is necessary because, in some
  5201      situations, the C compiler optimizes Lisp objects away, so that
  5202      only a pointer to them remains.  Example:
  5203 
  5204      DEFUN ("testme", Ftestme, Stestme, 0, 0, 0, "")
  5205      ()
  5206      {
  5207        Lisp_Object obj = build_string ("test");
  5208        struct Lisp_String *s = XSTRING (obj);
  5209        garbage_collect ();
  5210        fprintf (stderr, "test '%s'\n", s->u.s.data);
  5211        return Qnil;
  5212      }
  5213 
  5214      Here, `obj' isn't really used, and the compiler optimizes it
  5215      away.  The only reference to the life string is through the
  5216      pointer `s'.  */
  5217 
  5218   for (pp = start; (void const *) pp < end; pp += GC_POINTER_ALIGNMENT)
  5219     {
  5220       void *p = *(void *const *) pp;
  5221       mark_maybe_pointer (p, false);
  5222 
  5223       /* Unmask any struct Lisp_Symbol pointer that make_lisp_symbol
  5224          previously disguised by adding the address of 'lispsym'.
  5225          On a host with 32-bit pointers and 64-bit Lisp_Objects,
  5226          a Lisp_Object might be split into registers saved into
  5227          non-adjacent words and P might be the low-order word's value.  */
  5228       intptr_t ip;
  5229       ckd_add (&ip, (intptr_t) p, (intptr_t) lispsym);
  5230       mark_maybe_pointer ((void *) ip, true);
  5231     }
  5232 }
  5233 
  5234 #ifndef HAVE___BUILTIN_UNWIND_INIT
  5235 
  5236 # ifdef GC_SETJMP_WORKS
  5237 static void
  5238 test_setjmp (void)
  5239 {
  5240 }
  5241 # else
  5242 
  5243 static bool setjmp_tested_p;
  5244 static int longjmps_done;
  5245 
  5246 #  define SETJMP_WILL_LIKELY_WORK "\
  5247 \n\
  5248 Emacs garbage collector has been changed to use conservative stack\n\
  5249 marking.  Emacs has determined that the method it uses to do the\n\
  5250 marking will likely work on your system, but this isn't sure.\n\
  5251 \n\
  5252 If you are a system-programmer, or can get the help of a local wizard\n\
  5253 who is, please take a look at the function mark_c_stack in alloc.c, and\n\
  5254 verify that the methods used are appropriate for your system.\n\
  5255 \n\
  5256 Please mail the result to <emacs-devel@gnu.org>.\n\
  5257 "
  5258 
  5259 #  define SETJMP_WILL_NOT_WORK "\
  5260 \n\
  5261 Emacs garbage collector has been changed to use conservative stack\n\
  5262 marking.  Emacs has determined that the default method it uses to do the\n\
  5263 marking will not work on your system.  We will need a system-dependent\n\
  5264 solution for your system.\n\
  5265 \n\
  5266 Please take a look at the function mark_c_stack in alloc.c, and\n\
  5267 try to find a way to make it work on your system.\n\
  5268 \n\
  5269 Note that you may get false negatives, depending on the compiler.\n\
  5270 In particular, you need to use -O with GCC for this test.\n\
  5271 \n\
  5272 Please mail the result to <emacs-devel@gnu.org>.\n\
  5273 "
  5274 
  5275 
  5276 /* Perform a quick check if it looks like setjmp saves registers in a
  5277    jmp_buf.  Print a message to stderr saying so.  When this test
  5278    succeeds, this is _not_ a proof that setjmp is sufficient for
  5279    conservative stack marking.  Only the sources or a disassembly
  5280    can prove that.  */
  5281 
  5282 static void
  5283 test_setjmp (void)
  5284 {
  5285   if (setjmp_tested_p)
  5286     return;
  5287   setjmp_tested_p = true;
  5288   char buf[10];
  5289   register int x;
  5290   sys_jmp_buf jbuf;
  5291 
  5292   /* Arrange for X to be put in a register.  */
  5293   sprintf (buf, "1");
  5294   x = strlen (buf);
  5295   x = 2 * x - 1;
  5296 
  5297   sys_setjmp (jbuf);
  5298   if (longjmps_done == 1)
  5299     {
  5300       /* Came here after the longjmp at the end of the function.
  5301 
  5302          If x == 1, the longjmp has restored the register to its
  5303          value before the setjmp, and we can hope that setjmp
  5304          saves all such registers in the jmp_buf, although that
  5305          isn't sure.
  5306 
  5307          For other values of X, either something really strange is
  5308          taking place, or the setjmp just didn't save the register.  */
  5309 
  5310       if (x == 1)
  5311         fputs (SETJMP_WILL_LIKELY_WORK, stderr);
  5312       else
  5313         {
  5314           fputs (SETJMP_WILL_NOT_WORK, stderr);
  5315           exit (1);
  5316         }
  5317     }
  5318 
  5319   ++longjmps_done;
  5320   x = 2;
  5321   if (longjmps_done == 1)
  5322     sys_longjmp (jbuf, 1);
  5323 }
  5324 # endif /* ! GC_SETJMP_WORKS */
  5325 #endif /* ! HAVE___BUILTIN_UNWIND_INIT */
  5326 
  5327 /* The type of an object near the stack top, whose address can be used
  5328    as a stack scan limit.  */
  5329 typedef union
  5330 {
  5331   /* Make sure stack_top and m_stack_bottom are properly aligned as GC
  5332      expects.  */
  5333   Lisp_Object o;
  5334   void *p;
  5335 #ifndef HAVE___BUILTIN_UNWIND_INIT
  5336   sys_jmp_buf j;
  5337   char c;
  5338 #endif
  5339 } stacktop_sentry;
  5340 
  5341 /* Set *P to the address of the top of the stack.  This must be a
  5342    macro, not a function, so that it is executed in the caller's
  5343    environment.  It is not inside a do-while so that its storage
  5344    survives the macro.  Callers should be declared NO_INLINE.  */
  5345 #ifdef HAVE___BUILTIN_UNWIND_INIT
  5346 # define SET_STACK_TOP_ADDRESS(p)       \
  5347    stacktop_sentry sentry;              \
  5348    *(p) = NEAR_STACK_TOP (&sentry)
  5349 #else
  5350 # define SET_STACK_TOP_ADDRESS(p)               \
  5351    stacktop_sentry sentry;                      \
  5352    test_setjmp ();                              \
  5353    sys_setjmp (sentry.j);                       \
  5354    *(p) = NEAR_STACK_TOP (&sentry + (stack_bottom < &sentry.c))
  5355 #endif
  5356 
  5357 /* Mark live Lisp objects on the C stack.
  5358 
  5359    There are several system-dependent problems to consider when
  5360    porting this to new architectures:
  5361 
  5362    Processor Registers
  5363 
  5364    We have to mark Lisp objects in CPU registers that can hold local
  5365    variables or are used to pass parameters.
  5366 
  5367    If __builtin_unwind_init is available, it should suffice to save
  5368    registers.
  5369 
  5370    Otherwise, assume that calling setjmp saves registers we need
  5371    to see in a jmp_buf which itself lies on the stack.  This doesn't
  5372    have to be true!  It must be verified for each system, possibly
  5373    by taking a look at the source code of setjmp.
  5374 
  5375    Stack Layout
  5376 
  5377    Architectures differ in the way their processor stack is organized.
  5378    For example, the stack might look like this
  5379 
  5380      +----------------+
  5381      |  Lisp_Object   |  size = 4
  5382      +----------------+
  5383      | something else |  size = 2
  5384      +----------------+
  5385      |  Lisp_Object   |  size = 4
  5386      +----------------+
  5387      |  ...           |
  5388 
  5389    In such a case, not every Lisp_Object will be aligned equally.  To
  5390    find all Lisp_Object on the stack it won't be sufficient to walk
  5391    the stack in steps of 4 bytes.  Instead, two passes will be
  5392    necessary, one starting at the start of the stack, and a second
  5393    pass starting at the start of the stack + 2.  Likewise, if the
  5394    minimal alignment of Lisp_Objects on the stack is 1, four passes
  5395    would be necessary, each one starting with one byte more offset
  5396    from the stack start.  */
  5397 
  5398 void
  5399 mark_c_stack (char const *bottom, char const *end)
  5400 {
  5401   /* This assumes that the stack is a contiguous region in memory.  If
  5402      that's not the case, something has to be done here to iterate
  5403      over the stack segments.  */
  5404   mark_memory (bottom, end);
  5405 
  5406   /* Allow for marking a secondary stack, like the register stack on the
  5407      ia64.  */
  5408 #ifdef GC_MARK_SECONDARY_STACK
  5409   GC_MARK_SECONDARY_STACK ();
  5410 #endif
  5411 }
  5412 
  5413 /* flush_stack_call_func is the trampoline function that flushes
  5414    registers to the stack, and then calls FUNC.  ARG is passed through
  5415    to FUNC verbatim.
  5416 
  5417    This function must be called whenever Emacs is about to release the
  5418    global interpreter lock.  This lets the garbage collector easily
  5419    find roots in registers on threads that are not actively running
  5420    Lisp.
  5421 
  5422    It is invalid to run any Lisp code or to allocate any GC memory
  5423    from FUNC.
  5424 
  5425    Note: all register spilling is done in flush_stack_call_func before
  5426    flush_stack_call_func1 is activated.
  5427 
  5428    flush_stack_call_func1 is responsible for identifying the stack
  5429    address range to be scanned.  It *must* be carefully kept as
  5430    noinline to make sure that registers has been spilled before it is
  5431    called, otherwise given __builtin_frame_address (0) typically
  5432    returns the frame pointer (base pointer) and not the stack pointer
  5433    [1] GC will miss to scan callee-saved registers content
  5434    (Bug#41357).
  5435 
  5436    [1] <https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Return-Address.html>.  */
  5437 
  5438 NO_INLINE void
  5439 flush_stack_call_func1 (void (*func) (void *arg), void *arg)
  5440 {
  5441   void *end;
  5442   struct thread_state *self = current_thread;
  5443   SET_STACK_TOP_ADDRESS (&end);
  5444   self->stack_top = end;
  5445   func (arg);
  5446   eassert (current_thread == self);
  5447 }
  5448 
  5449 /* Determine whether it is safe to access memory at address P.  */
  5450 static int
  5451 valid_pointer_p (void *p)
  5452 {
  5453 #ifdef WINDOWSNT
  5454   return w32_valid_pointer_p (p, 16);
  5455 #else
  5456 
  5457   if (ADDRESS_SANITIZER)
  5458     return p ? -1 : 0;
  5459 
  5460   int fd[2];
  5461   static int under_rr_state;
  5462 
  5463   if (!under_rr_state)
  5464     under_rr_state = getenv ("RUNNING_UNDER_RR") ? -1 : 1;
  5465   if (under_rr_state < 0)
  5466     return under_rr_state;
  5467 
  5468   /* Obviously, we cannot just access it (we would SEGV trying), so we
  5469      trick the o/s to tell us whether p is a valid pointer.
  5470      Unfortunately, we cannot use NULL_DEVICE here, as emacs_write may
  5471      not validate p in that case.  */
  5472 
  5473   if (emacs_pipe (fd) == 0)
  5474     {
  5475       bool valid = emacs_write (fd[1], p, 16) == 16;
  5476       emacs_close (fd[1]);
  5477       emacs_close (fd[0]);
  5478       return valid;
  5479     }
  5480 
  5481   return -1;
  5482 #endif
  5483 }
  5484 
  5485 /* Return 2 if OBJ is a killed or special buffer object, 1 if OBJ is a
  5486    valid lisp object, 0 if OBJ is NOT a valid lisp object, or -1 if we
  5487    cannot validate OBJ.  This function can be quite slow, and is used
  5488    only in debugging.  */
  5489 
  5490 int
  5491 valid_lisp_object_p (Lisp_Object obj)
  5492 {
  5493   if (FIXNUMP (obj))
  5494     return 1;
  5495 
  5496   void *p = XPNTR (obj);
  5497   if (PURE_P (p))
  5498     return 1;
  5499 
  5500   if (BARE_SYMBOL_P (obj) && c_symbol_p (p))
  5501     return ((char *) p - (char *) lispsym) % sizeof lispsym[0] == 0;
  5502 
  5503   if (p == &buffer_defaults || p == &buffer_local_symbols)
  5504     return 2;
  5505 
  5506   if (pdumper_object_p (p))
  5507     return pdumper_object_p_precise (p) ? 1 : 0;
  5508 
  5509   struct mem_node *m = mem_find (p);
  5510 
  5511   if (m == MEM_NIL)
  5512     {
  5513       int valid = valid_pointer_p (p);
  5514       if (valid <= 0)
  5515         return valid;
  5516 
  5517       /* Strings and conses produced by AUTO_STRING etc. all get here.  */
  5518       if (SUBRP (obj) || STRINGP (obj) || CONSP (obj))
  5519         return 1;
  5520 
  5521       return 0;
  5522     }
  5523 
  5524   switch (m->type)
  5525     {
  5526     case MEM_TYPE_NON_LISP:
  5527     case MEM_TYPE_SPARE:
  5528       return 0;
  5529 
  5530     case MEM_TYPE_CONS:
  5531       return live_cons_p (m, p);
  5532 
  5533     case MEM_TYPE_STRING:
  5534       return live_string_p (m, p);
  5535 
  5536     case MEM_TYPE_SYMBOL:
  5537       return live_symbol_p (m, p);
  5538 
  5539     case MEM_TYPE_FLOAT:
  5540       return live_float_p (m, p);
  5541 
  5542     case MEM_TYPE_VECTORLIKE:
  5543       return live_large_vector_p (m, p);
  5544 
  5545     case MEM_TYPE_VECTOR_BLOCK:
  5546       return live_small_vector_p (m, p);
  5547 
  5548     default:
  5549       break;
  5550     }
  5551 
  5552   return 0;
  5553 }
  5554 
  5555 /***********************************************************************
  5556                        Pure Storage Management
  5557  ***********************************************************************/
  5558 
  5559 /* Allocate room for SIZE bytes from pure Lisp storage and return a
  5560    pointer to it.  TYPE is the Lisp type for which the memory is
  5561    allocated.  TYPE < 0 means it's not used for a Lisp object,
  5562    and that the result should have an alignment of -TYPE.
  5563 
  5564    The bytes are initially zero.
  5565 
  5566    If pure space is exhausted, allocate space from the heap.  This is
  5567    merely an expedient to let Emacs warn that pure space was exhausted
  5568    and that Emacs should be rebuilt with a larger pure space.  */
  5569 
  5570 static void *
  5571 pure_alloc (size_t size, int type)
  5572 {
  5573   void *result;
  5574   static bool pure_overflow_warned = false;
  5575 
  5576  again:
  5577   if (type >= 0)
  5578     {
  5579       /* Allocate space for a Lisp object from the beginning of the free
  5580          space with taking account of alignment.  */
  5581       result = pointer_align (purebeg + pure_bytes_used_lisp, LISP_ALIGNMENT);
  5582       pure_bytes_used_lisp = ((char *)result - (char *)purebeg) + size;
  5583     }
  5584   else
  5585     {
  5586       /* Allocate space for a non-Lisp object from the end of the free
  5587          space.  */
  5588       ptrdiff_t unaligned_non_lisp = pure_bytes_used_non_lisp + size;
  5589       char *unaligned = purebeg + pure_size - unaligned_non_lisp;
  5590       int decr = (intptr_t) unaligned & (-1 - type);
  5591       pure_bytes_used_non_lisp = unaligned_non_lisp + decr;
  5592       result = unaligned - decr;
  5593     }
  5594   pure_bytes_used = pure_bytes_used_lisp + pure_bytes_used_non_lisp;
  5595 
  5596   if (pure_bytes_used <= pure_size)
  5597     return result;
  5598 
  5599   if (!pure_overflow_warned)
  5600     {
  5601       message ("Pure Lisp storage overflowed");
  5602       pure_overflow_warned = true;
  5603     }
  5604 
  5605   /* Don't allocate a large amount here,
  5606      because it might get mmap'd and then its address
  5607      might not be usable.  */
  5608   int small_amount = 10000;
  5609   eassert (size <= small_amount - LISP_ALIGNMENT);
  5610   purebeg = xzalloc (small_amount);
  5611   pure_size = small_amount;
  5612   pure_bytes_used_before_overflow += pure_bytes_used - size;
  5613   pure_bytes_used = 0;
  5614   pure_bytes_used_lisp = pure_bytes_used_non_lisp = 0;
  5615 
  5616   /* Can't GC if pure storage overflowed because we can't determine
  5617      if something is a pure object or not.  */
  5618   garbage_collection_inhibited++;
  5619   goto again;
  5620 }
  5621 
  5622 /* Print a warning if PURESIZE is too small.  */
  5623 
  5624 void
  5625 check_pure_size (void)
  5626 {
  5627   if (pure_bytes_used_before_overflow)
  5628     message (("emacs:0:Pure Lisp storage overflow (approx. %jd"
  5629               " bytes needed)"),
  5630              pure_bytes_used + pure_bytes_used_before_overflow);
  5631 }
  5632 
  5633 /* Find the byte sequence {DATA[0], ..., DATA[NBYTES-1], '\0'} from
  5634    the non-Lisp data pool of the pure storage, and return its start
  5635    address.  Return NULL if not found.  */
  5636 
  5637 static char *
  5638 find_string_data_in_pure (const char *data, ptrdiff_t nbytes)
  5639 {
  5640   int i;
  5641   ptrdiff_t skip, bm_skip[256], last_char_skip, infinity, start, start_max;
  5642   const unsigned char *p;
  5643   char *non_lisp_beg;
  5644 
  5645   if (pure_bytes_used_non_lisp <= nbytes)
  5646     return NULL;
  5647 
  5648   /* Set up the Boyer-Moore table.  */
  5649   skip = nbytes + 1;
  5650   for (i = 0; i < 256; i++)
  5651     bm_skip[i] = skip;
  5652 
  5653   p = (const unsigned char *) data;
  5654   while (--skip > 0)
  5655     bm_skip[*p++] = skip;
  5656 
  5657   last_char_skip = bm_skip['\0'];
  5658 
  5659   non_lisp_beg = purebeg + pure_size - pure_bytes_used_non_lisp;
  5660   start_max = pure_bytes_used_non_lisp - (nbytes + 1);
  5661 
  5662   /* See the comments in the function `boyer_moore' (search.c) for the
  5663      use of `infinity'.  */
  5664   infinity = pure_bytes_used_non_lisp + 1;
  5665   bm_skip['\0'] = infinity;
  5666 
  5667   p = (const unsigned char *) non_lisp_beg + nbytes;
  5668   start = 0;
  5669   do
  5670     {
  5671       /* Check the last character (== '\0').  */
  5672       do
  5673         {
  5674           start += bm_skip[*(p + start)];
  5675         }
  5676       while (start <= start_max);
  5677 
  5678       if (start < infinity)
  5679         /* Couldn't find the last character.  */
  5680         return NULL;
  5681 
  5682       /* No less than `infinity' means we could find the last
  5683          character at `p[start - infinity]'.  */
  5684       start -= infinity;
  5685 
  5686       /* Check the remaining characters.  */
  5687       if (memcmp (data, non_lisp_beg + start, nbytes) == 0)
  5688         /* Found.  */
  5689         return non_lisp_beg + start;
  5690 
  5691       start += last_char_skip;
  5692     }
  5693   while (start <= start_max);
  5694 
  5695   return NULL;
  5696 }
  5697 
  5698 
  5699 /* Return a string allocated in pure space.  DATA is a buffer holding
  5700    NCHARS characters, and NBYTES bytes of string data.  MULTIBYTE
  5701    means make the result string multibyte.
  5702 
  5703    Must get an error if pure storage is full, since if it cannot hold
  5704    a large string it may be able to hold conses that point to that
  5705    string; then the string is not protected from gc.  */
  5706 
  5707 Lisp_Object
  5708 make_pure_string (const char *data,
  5709                   ptrdiff_t nchars, ptrdiff_t nbytes, bool multibyte)
  5710 {
  5711   Lisp_Object string;
  5712   struct Lisp_String *s = pure_alloc (sizeof *s, Lisp_String);
  5713   s->u.s.data = (unsigned char *) find_string_data_in_pure (data, nbytes);
  5714   if (s->u.s.data == NULL)
  5715     {
  5716       s->u.s.data = pure_alloc (nbytes + 1, -1);
  5717       memcpy (s->u.s.data, data, nbytes);
  5718       s->u.s.data[nbytes] = '\0';
  5719     }
  5720   s->u.s.size = nchars;
  5721   s->u.s.size_byte = multibyte ? nbytes : -1;
  5722   s->u.s.intervals = NULL;
  5723   XSETSTRING (string, s);
  5724   return string;
  5725 }
  5726 
  5727 /* Return a string allocated in pure space.  Do not
  5728    allocate the string data, just point to DATA.  */
  5729 
  5730 Lisp_Object
  5731 make_pure_c_string (const char *data, ptrdiff_t nchars)
  5732 {
  5733   Lisp_Object string;
  5734   struct Lisp_String *s = pure_alloc (sizeof *s, Lisp_String);
  5735   s->u.s.size = nchars;
  5736   s->u.s.size_byte = -2;
  5737   s->u.s.data = (unsigned char *) data;
  5738   s->u.s.intervals = NULL;
  5739   XSETSTRING (string, s);
  5740   return string;
  5741 }
  5742 
  5743 static Lisp_Object purecopy (Lisp_Object obj);
  5744 
  5745 /* Return a cons allocated from pure space.  Give it pure copies
  5746    of CAR as car and CDR as cdr.  */
  5747 
  5748 Lisp_Object
  5749 pure_cons (Lisp_Object car, Lisp_Object cdr)
  5750 {
  5751   Lisp_Object new;
  5752   struct Lisp_Cons *p = pure_alloc (sizeof *p, Lisp_Cons);
  5753   XSETCONS (new, p);
  5754   XSETCAR (new, purecopy (car));
  5755   XSETCDR (new, purecopy (cdr));
  5756   return new;
  5757 }
  5758 
  5759 
  5760 /* Value is a float object with value NUM allocated from pure space.  */
  5761 
  5762 static Lisp_Object
  5763 make_pure_float (double num)
  5764 {
  5765   Lisp_Object new;
  5766   struct Lisp_Float *p = pure_alloc (sizeof *p, Lisp_Float);
  5767   XSETFLOAT (new, p);
  5768   XFLOAT_INIT (new, num);
  5769   return new;
  5770 }
  5771 
  5772 /* Value is a bignum object with value VALUE allocated from pure
  5773    space.  */
  5774 
  5775 static Lisp_Object
  5776 make_pure_bignum (Lisp_Object value)
  5777 {
  5778   mpz_t const *n = xbignum_val (value);
  5779   size_t i, nlimbs = mpz_size (*n);
  5780   size_t nbytes = nlimbs * sizeof (mp_limb_t);
  5781   mp_limb_t *pure_limbs;
  5782   mp_size_t new_size;
  5783 
  5784   struct Lisp_Bignum *b = pure_alloc (sizeof *b, Lisp_Vectorlike);
  5785   XSETPVECTYPESIZE (b, PVEC_BIGNUM, 0, VECSIZE (struct Lisp_Bignum));
  5786 
  5787   int limb_alignment = alignof (mp_limb_t);
  5788   pure_limbs = pure_alloc (nbytes, - limb_alignment);
  5789   for (i = 0; i < nlimbs; ++i)
  5790     pure_limbs[i] = mpz_getlimbn (*n, i);
  5791 
  5792   new_size = nlimbs;
  5793   if (mpz_sgn (*n) < 0)
  5794     new_size = -new_size;
  5795 
  5796   mpz_roinit_n (b->value, pure_limbs, new_size);
  5797 
  5798   return make_lisp_ptr (b, Lisp_Vectorlike);
  5799 }
  5800 
  5801 /* Return a vector with room for LEN Lisp_Objects allocated from
  5802    pure space.  */
  5803 
  5804 static Lisp_Object
  5805 make_pure_vector (ptrdiff_t len)
  5806 {
  5807   Lisp_Object new;
  5808   size_t size = header_size + len * word_size;
  5809   struct Lisp_Vector *p = pure_alloc (size, Lisp_Vectorlike);
  5810   XSETVECTOR (new, p);
  5811   XVECTOR (new)->header.size = len;
  5812   return new;
  5813 }
  5814 
  5815 /* Copy all contents and parameters of TABLE to a new table allocated
  5816    from pure space, return the purified table.  */
  5817 static struct Lisp_Hash_Table *
  5818 purecopy_hash_table (struct Lisp_Hash_Table *table)
  5819 {
  5820   eassert (NILP (table->weak));
  5821   eassert (table->purecopy);
  5822 
  5823   struct Lisp_Hash_Table *pure = pure_alloc (sizeof *pure, Lisp_Vectorlike);
  5824   struct hash_table_test pure_test = table->test;
  5825 
  5826   /* Purecopy the hash table test.  */
  5827   pure_test.name = purecopy (table->test.name);
  5828   pure_test.user_hash_function = purecopy (table->test.user_hash_function);
  5829   pure_test.user_cmp_function = purecopy (table->test.user_cmp_function);
  5830 
  5831   pure->header = table->header;
  5832   pure->weak = purecopy (Qnil);
  5833   pure->hash = purecopy (table->hash);
  5834   pure->next = purecopy (table->next);
  5835   pure->index = purecopy (table->index);
  5836   pure->count = table->count;
  5837   pure->next_free = table->next_free;
  5838   pure->purecopy = table->purecopy;
  5839   eassert (!pure->mutable);
  5840   pure->rehash_threshold = table->rehash_threshold;
  5841   pure->rehash_size = table->rehash_size;
  5842   pure->key_and_value = purecopy (table->key_and_value);
  5843   pure->test = pure_test;
  5844 
  5845   return pure;
  5846 }
  5847 
  5848 DEFUN ("purecopy", Fpurecopy, Spurecopy, 1, 1, 0,
  5849        doc: /* Make a copy of object OBJ in pure storage.
  5850 Recursively copies contents of vectors and cons cells.
  5851 Does not copy symbols.  Copies strings without text properties.  */)
  5852   (register Lisp_Object obj)
  5853 {
  5854   if (NILP (Vpurify_flag))
  5855     return obj;
  5856   else if (MARKERP (obj) || OVERLAYP (obj) || SYMBOLP (obj))
  5857     /* Can't purify those.  */
  5858     return obj;
  5859   else
  5860     return purecopy (obj);
  5861 }
  5862 
  5863 /* Pinned objects are marked before every GC cycle.  */
  5864 static struct pinned_object
  5865 {
  5866   Lisp_Object object;
  5867   struct pinned_object *next;
  5868 } *pinned_objects;
  5869 
  5870 static Lisp_Object
  5871 purecopy (Lisp_Object obj)
  5872 {
  5873   if (FIXNUMP (obj)
  5874       || (! SYMBOLP (obj) && PURE_P (XPNTR (obj)))
  5875       || SUBRP (obj))
  5876     return obj;    /* Already pure.  */
  5877 
  5878   if (STRINGP (obj) && XSTRING (obj)->u.s.intervals)
  5879     message_with_string ("Dropping text-properties while making string `%s' pure",
  5880                          obj, true);
  5881 
  5882   if (HASH_TABLE_P (Vpurify_flag)) /* Hash consing.  */
  5883     {
  5884       Lisp_Object tmp = Fgethash (obj, Vpurify_flag, Qnil);
  5885       if (!NILP (tmp))
  5886         return tmp;
  5887     }
  5888 
  5889   if (CONSP (obj))
  5890     obj = pure_cons (XCAR (obj), XCDR (obj));
  5891   else if (FLOATP (obj))
  5892     obj = make_pure_float (XFLOAT_DATA (obj));
  5893   else if (STRINGP (obj))
  5894     obj = make_pure_string (SSDATA (obj), SCHARS (obj),
  5895                             SBYTES (obj),
  5896                             STRING_MULTIBYTE (obj));
  5897   else if (HASH_TABLE_P (obj))
  5898     {
  5899       struct Lisp_Hash_Table *table = XHASH_TABLE (obj);
  5900       /* Do not purify hash tables which haven't been defined with
  5901          :purecopy as non-nil or are weak - they aren't guaranteed to
  5902          not change.  */
  5903       if (!NILP (table->weak) || !table->purecopy)
  5904         {
  5905           /* Instead, add the hash table to the list of pinned objects,
  5906              so that it will be marked during GC.  */
  5907           struct pinned_object *o = xmalloc (sizeof *o);
  5908           o->object = obj;
  5909           o->next = pinned_objects;
  5910           pinned_objects = o;
  5911           return obj; /* Don't hash cons it.  */
  5912         }
  5913 
  5914       struct Lisp_Hash_Table *h = purecopy_hash_table (table);
  5915       XSET_HASH_TABLE (obj, h);
  5916     }
  5917   else if (COMPILEDP (obj) || VECTORP (obj) || RECORDP (obj))
  5918     {
  5919       struct Lisp_Vector *objp = XVECTOR (obj);
  5920       ptrdiff_t nbytes = vector_nbytes (objp);
  5921       struct Lisp_Vector *vec = pure_alloc (nbytes, Lisp_Vectorlike);
  5922       register ptrdiff_t i;
  5923       ptrdiff_t size = ASIZE (obj);
  5924       if (size & PSEUDOVECTOR_FLAG)
  5925         size &= PSEUDOVECTOR_SIZE_MASK;
  5926       memcpy (vec, objp, nbytes);
  5927       for (i = 0; i < size; i++)
  5928         vec->contents[i] = purecopy (vec->contents[i]);
  5929       /* Byte code strings must be pinned.  */
  5930       if (COMPILEDP (obj) && size >= 2 && STRINGP (vec->contents[1])
  5931           && !STRING_MULTIBYTE (vec->contents[1]))
  5932         pin_string (vec->contents[1]);
  5933       XSETVECTOR (obj, vec);
  5934     }
  5935   else if (BARE_SYMBOL_P (obj))
  5936     {
  5937       if (!XBARE_SYMBOL (obj)->u.s.pinned && !c_symbol_p (XBARE_SYMBOL (obj)))
  5938         { /* We can't purify them, but they appear in many pure objects.
  5939              Mark them as `pinned' so we know to mark them at every GC cycle.  */
  5940           XBARE_SYMBOL (obj)->u.s.pinned = true;
  5941           symbol_block_pinned = symbol_block;
  5942         }
  5943       /* Don't hash-cons it.  */
  5944       return obj;
  5945     }
  5946   else if (BIGNUMP (obj))
  5947     obj = make_pure_bignum (obj);
  5948   else
  5949     {
  5950       AUTO_STRING (fmt, "Don't know how to purify: %S");
  5951       Fsignal (Qerror, list1 (CALLN (Fformat, fmt, obj)));
  5952     }
  5953 
  5954   if (HASH_TABLE_P (Vpurify_flag)) /* Hash consing.  */
  5955     Fputhash (obj, obj, Vpurify_flag);
  5956 
  5957   return obj;
  5958 }
  5959 
  5960 
  5961 
  5962 /***********************************************************************
  5963                           Protection from GC
  5964  ***********************************************************************/
  5965 
  5966 /* Put an entry in staticvec, pointing at the variable with address
  5967    VARADDRESS.  */
  5968 
  5969 void
  5970 staticpro (Lisp_Object const *varaddress)
  5971 {
  5972   for (int i = 0; i < staticidx; i++)
  5973     eassert (staticvec[i] != varaddress);
  5974   if (staticidx >= NSTATICS)
  5975     fatal ("NSTATICS too small; try increasing and recompiling Emacs.");
  5976   staticvec[staticidx++] = varaddress;
  5977 }
  5978 
  5979 
  5980 /***********************************************************************
  5981                           Protection from GC
  5982  ***********************************************************************/
  5983 
  5984 /* Temporarily prevent garbage collection.  Temporarily bump
  5985    consing_until_gc to speed up maybe_gc when GC is inhibited.  */
  5986 
  5987 static void
  5988 allow_garbage_collection (intmax_t consing)
  5989 {
  5990   consing_until_gc = consing - (HI_THRESHOLD - consing_until_gc);
  5991   garbage_collection_inhibited--;
  5992 }
  5993 
  5994 specpdl_ref
  5995 inhibit_garbage_collection (void)
  5996 {
  5997   specpdl_ref count = SPECPDL_INDEX ();
  5998   record_unwind_protect_intmax (allow_garbage_collection, consing_until_gc);
  5999   garbage_collection_inhibited++;
  6000   consing_until_gc = HI_THRESHOLD;
  6001   return count;
  6002 }
  6003 
  6004 /* Return the number of bytes in N objects each of size S, guarding
  6005    against overflow if size_t is narrower than byte_ct.  */
  6006 
  6007 static byte_ct
  6008 object_bytes (object_ct n, size_t s)
  6009 {
  6010   byte_ct b = s;
  6011   return n * b;
  6012 }
  6013 
  6014 /* Calculate total bytes of live objects.  */
  6015 
  6016 static byte_ct
  6017 total_bytes_of_live_objects (void)
  6018 {
  6019   byte_ct tot = 0;
  6020   tot += object_bytes (gcstat.total_conses, sizeof (struct Lisp_Cons));
  6021   tot += object_bytes (gcstat.total_symbols, sizeof (struct Lisp_Symbol));
  6022   tot += gcstat.total_string_bytes;
  6023   tot += object_bytes (gcstat.total_vector_slots, word_size);
  6024   tot += object_bytes (gcstat.total_floats, sizeof (struct Lisp_Float));
  6025   tot += object_bytes (gcstat.total_intervals, sizeof (struct interval));
  6026   tot += object_bytes (gcstat.total_strings, sizeof (struct Lisp_String));
  6027   return tot;
  6028 }
  6029 
  6030 #ifdef HAVE_WINDOW_SYSTEM
  6031 
  6032 /* Remove unmarked font-spec and font-entity objects from ENTRY, which is
  6033    (DRIVER-TYPE NUM-FRAMES FONT-CACHE-DATA ...), and return changed entry.  */
  6034 
  6035 static Lisp_Object
  6036 compact_font_cache_entry (Lisp_Object entry)
  6037 {
  6038   Lisp_Object tail, *prev = &entry;
  6039 
  6040   for (tail = entry; CONSP (tail); tail = XCDR (tail))
  6041     {
  6042       bool drop = 0;
  6043       Lisp_Object obj = XCAR (tail);
  6044 
  6045       /* Consider OBJ if it is (font-spec . [font-entity font-entity ...]).  */
  6046       if (CONSP (obj) && GC_FONT_SPEC_P (XCAR (obj))
  6047           && !vectorlike_marked_p (&GC_XFONT_SPEC (XCAR (obj))->header)
  6048           /* Don't use VECTORP here, as that calls ASIZE, which could
  6049              hit assertion violation during GC.  */
  6050           && (VECTORLIKEP (XCDR (obj))
  6051               && ! (gc_asize (XCDR (obj)) & PSEUDOVECTOR_FLAG)))
  6052         {
  6053           ptrdiff_t i, size = gc_asize (XCDR (obj));
  6054           Lisp_Object obj_cdr = XCDR (obj);
  6055 
  6056           /* If font-spec is not marked, most likely all font-entities
  6057              are not marked too.  But we must be sure that nothing is
  6058              marked within OBJ before we really drop it.  */
  6059           for (i = 0; i < size; i++)
  6060             {
  6061               Lisp_Object objlist;
  6062 
  6063               if (vectorlike_marked_p (
  6064                     &GC_XFONT_ENTITY (AREF (obj_cdr, i))->header))
  6065                 break;
  6066 
  6067               objlist = AREF (AREF (obj_cdr, i), FONT_OBJLIST_INDEX);
  6068               for (; CONSP (objlist); objlist = XCDR (objlist))
  6069                 {
  6070                   Lisp_Object val = XCAR (objlist);
  6071                   struct font *font = GC_XFONT_OBJECT (val);
  6072 
  6073                   if (!NILP (AREF (val, FONT_TYPE_INDEX))
  6074                       && vectorlike_marked_p (&font->header))
  6075                     break;
  6076                 }
  6077               if (CONSP (objlist))
  6078                 {
  6079                   /* Found a marked font, bail out.  */
  6080                   break;
  6081                 }
  6082             }
  6083 
  6084           if (i == size)
  6085             {
  6086               /* No marked fonts were found, so this entire font
  6087                  entity can be dropped.  */
  6088               drop = 1;
  6089             }
  6090         }
  6091       if (drop)
  6092         *prev = XCDR (tail);
  6093       else
  6094         prev = xcdr_addr (tail);
  6095     }
  6096   return entry;
  6097 }
  6098 
  6099 /* Compact font caches on all terminals and mark
  6100    everything which is still here after compaction.  */
  6101 
  6102 static void
  6103 compact_font_caches (void)
  6104 {
  6105   struct terminal *t;
  6106 
  6107   for (t = terminal_list; t; t = t->next_terminal)
  6108     {
  6109       Lisp_Object cache = TERMINAL_FONT_CACHE (t);
  6110       /* Inhibit compacting the caches if the user so wishes.  Some of
  6111          the users don't mind a larger memory footprint, but do mind
  6112          slower redisplay.  */
  6113       if (!inhibit_compacting_font_caches
  6114           && CONSP (cache))
  6115         {
  6116           Lisp_Object entry;
  6117 
  6118           for (entry = XCDR (cache); CONSP (entry); entry = XCDR (entry))
  6119             XSETCAR (entry, compact_font_cache_entry (XCAR (entry)));
  6120         }
  6121       mark_object (cache);
  6122     }
  6123 }
  6124 
  6125 #else /* not HAVE_WINDOW_SYSTEM */
  6126 
  6127 #define compact_font_caches() (void)(0)
  6128 
  6129 #endif /* HAVE_WINDOW_SYSTEM */
  6130 
  6131 /* Remove (MARKER . DATA) entries with unmarked MARKER
  6132    from buffer undo LIST and return changed list.  */
  6133 
  6134 static Lisp_Object
  6135 compact_undo_list (Lisp_Object list)
  6136 {
  6137   Lisp_Object tail, *prev = &list;
  6138 
  6139   for (tail = list; CONSP (tail); tail = XCDR (tail))
  6140     {
  6141       if (CONSP (XCAR (tail))
  6142           && MARKERP (XCAR (XCAR (tail)))
  6143           && !vectorlike_marked_p (&XMARKER (XCAR (XCAR (tail)))->header))
  6144         *prev = XCDR (tail);
  6145       else
  6146         prev = xcdr_addr (tail);
  6147     }
  6148   return list;
  6149 }
  6150 
  6151 static void
  6152 mark_pinned_objects (void)
  6153 {
  6154   for (struct pinned_object *pobj = pinned_objects; pobj; pobj = pobj->next)
  6155     mark_object (pobj->object);
  6156 }
  6157 
  6158 static void
  6159 mark_pinned_symbols (void)
  6160 {
  6161   struct symbol_block *sblk;
  6162   int lim = (symbol_block_pinned == symbol_block
  6163              ? symbol_block_index : SYMBOL_BLOCK_SIZE);
  6164 
  6165   for (sblk = symbol_block_pinned; sblk; sblk = sblk->next)
  6166     {
  6167       struct Lisp_Symbol *sym = sblk->symbols, *end = sym + lim;
  6168       for (; sym < end; ++sym)
  6169         if (sym->u.s.pinned)
  6170           mark_object (make_lisp_symbol (sym));
  6171 
  6172       lim = SYMBOL_BLOCK_SIZE;
  6173     }
  6174 }
  6175 
  6176 static void
  6177 visit_vectorlike_root (struct gc_root_visitor visitor,
  6178                        struct Lisp_Vector *ptr,
  6179                        enum gc_root_type type)
  6180 {
  6181   ptrdiff_t size = ptr->header.size;
  6182   ptrdiff_t i;
  6183 
  6184   if (size & PSEUDOVECTOR_FLAG)
  6185     size &= PSEUDOVECTOR_SIZE_MASK;
  6186   for (i = 0; i < size; i++)
  6187     visitor.visit (&ptr->contents[i], type, visitor.data);
  6188 }
  6189 
  6190 static void
  6191 visit_buffer_root (struct gc_root_visitor visitor,
  6192                    struct buffer *buffer,
  6193                    enum gc_root_type type)
  6194 {
  6195   /* Buffers that are roots don't have intervals, an undo list, or
  6196      other constructs that real buffers have.  */
  6197   eassert (buffer->base_buffer == NULL);
  6198   eassert (buffer->overlays == NULL);
  6199 
  6200   /* Visit the buffer-locals.  */
  6201   visit_vectorlike_root (visitor, (struct Lisp_Vector *) buffer, type);
  6202 }
  6203 
  6204 /* Visit GC roots stored in the Emacs data section.  Used by both core
  6205    GC and by the portable dumping code.
  6206 
  6207    There are other GC roots of course, but these roots are dynamic
  6208    runtime data structures that pdump doesn't care about and so we can
  6209    continue to mark those directly in garbage_collect.  */
  6210 void
  6211 visit_static_gc_roots (struct gc_root_visitor visitor)
  6212 {
  6213   visit_buffer_root (visitor,
  6214                      &buffer_defaults,
  6215                      GC_ROOT_BUFFER_LOCAL_DEFAULT);
  6216   visit_buffer_root (visitor,
  6217                      &buffer_local_symbols,
  6218                      GC_ROOT_BUFFER_LOCAL_NAME);
  6219 
  6220   for (int i = 0; i < ARRAYELTS (lispsym); i++)
  6221     {
  6222       Lisp_Object sptr = builtin_lisp_symbol (i);
  6223       visitor.visit (&sptr, GC_ROOT_C_SYMBOL, visitor.data);
  6224     }
  6225 
  6226   for (int i = 0; i < staticidx; i++)
  6227     visitor.visit (staticvec[i], GC_ROOT_STATICPRO, visitor.data);
  6228 }
  6229 
  6230 static void
  6231 mark_object_root_visitor (Lisp_Object const *root_ptr,
  6232                           enum gc_root_type type,
  6233                           void *data)
  6234 {
  6235   mark_object (*root_ptr);
  6236 }
  6237 
  6238 /* List of weak hash tables we found during marking the Lisp heap.
  6239    NULL on entry to garbage_collect and after it returns.  */
  6240 static struct Lisp_Hash_Table *weak_hash_tables;
  6241 
  6242 NO_INLINE /* For better stack traces */
  6243 static void
  6244 mark_and_sweep_weak_table_contents (void)
  6245 {
  6246   struct Lisp_Hash_Table *h;
  6247   bool marked;
  6248 
  6249   /* Mark all keys and values that are in use.  Keep on marking until
  6250      there is no more change.  This is necessary for cases like
  6251      value-weak table A containing an entry X -> Y, where Y is used in a
  6252      key-weak table B, Z -> Y.  If B comes after A in the list of weak
  6253      tables, X -> Y might be removed from A, although when looking at B
  6254      one finds that it shouldn't.  */
  6255   do
  6256     {
  6257       marked = false;
  6258       for (h = weak_hash_tables; h; h = h->next_weak)
  6259         marked |= sweep_weak_table (h, false);
  6260     }
  6261   while (marked);
  6262 
  6263   /* Remove hash table entries that aren't used.  */
  6264   while (weak_hash_tables)
  6265     {
  6266       h = weak_hash_tables;
  6267       weak_hash_tables = h->next_weak;
  6268       h->next_weak = NULL;
  6269       sweep_weak_table (h, true);
  6270     }
  6271 }
  6272 
  6273 /* Return the number of bytes to cons between GCs, given THRESHOLD and
  6274    PERCENTAGE.  When calculating a threshold based on PERCENTAGE,
  6275    assume SINCE_GC bytes have been allocated since the most recent GC.
  6276    The returned value is positive and no greater than HI_THRESHOLD.  */
  6277 static EMACS_INT
  6278 consing_threshold (intmax_t threshold, Lisp_Object percentage,
  6279                    intmax_t since_gc)
  6280 {
  6281   if (!NILP (Vmemory_full))
  6282     return memory_full_cons_threshold;
  6283   else
  6284     {
  6285       threshold = max (threshold, GC_DEFAULT_THRESHOLD / 10);
  6286       if (FLOATP (percentage))
  6287         {
  6288           double tot = (XFLOAT_DATA (percentage)
  6289                         * (total_bytes_of_live_objects () + since_gc));
  6290           if (threshold < tot)
  6291             {
  6292               if (tot < HI_THRESHOLD)
  6293                 return tot;
  6294               else
  6295                 return HI_THRESHOLD;
  6296             }
  6297         }
  6298       return min (threshold, HI_THRESHOLD);
  6299     }
  6300 }
  6301 
  6302 /* Adjust consing_until_gc and gc_threshold, given THRESHOLD and PERCENTAGE.
  6303    Return the updated consing_until_gc.  */
  6304 
  6305 static EMACS_INT
  6306 bump_consing_until_gc (intmax_t threshold, Lisp_Object percentage)
  6307 {
  6308   /* Guesstimate that half the bytes allocated since the most
  6309      recent GC are still in use.  */
  6310   EMACS_INT since_gc = (gc_threshold - consing_until_gc) >> 1;
  6311   EMACS_INT new_gc_threshold = consing_threshold (threshold, percentage,
  6312                                                   since_gc);
  6313   consing_until_gc += new_gc_threshold - gc_threshold;
  6314   gc_threshold = new_gc_threshold;
  6315   return consing_until_gc;
  6316 }
  6317 
  6318 /* Watch changes to gc-cons-threshold.  */
  6319 static Lisp_Object
  6320 watch_gc_cons_threshold (Lisp_Object symbol, Lisp_Object newval,
  6321                          Lisp_Object operation, Lisp_Object where)
  6322 {
  6323   intmax_t threshold;
  6324   if (! (INTEGERP (newval) && integer_to_intmax (newval, &threshold)))
  6325     return Qnil;
  6326   bump_consing_until_gc (threshold, Vgc_cons_percentage);
  6327   return Qnil;
  6328 }
  6329 
  6330 /* Watch changes to gc-cons-percentage.  */
  6331 static Lisp_Object
  6332 watch_gc_cons_percentage (Lisp_Object symbol, Lisp_Object newval,
  6333                           Lisp_Object operation, Lisp_Object where)
  6334 {
  6335   bump_consing_until_gc (gc_cons_threshold, newval);
  6336   return Qnil;
  6337 }
  6338 
  6339 /* It may be time to collect garbage.  Recalculate consing_until_gc,
  6340    since it might depend on current usage, and do the garbage
  6341    collection if the recalculation says so.  */
  6342 void
  6343 maybe_garbage_collect (void)
  6344 {
  6345   if (bump_consing_until_gc (gc_cons_threshold, Vgc_cons_percentage) < 0)
  6346     garbage_collect ();
  6347 }
  6348 
  6349 static inline bool mark_stack_empty_p (void);
  6350 
  6351 /* Subroutine of Fgarbage_collect that does most of the work.  */
  6352 void
  6353 garbage_collect (void)
  6354 {
  6355   Lisp_Object tail, buffer;
  6356   char stack_top_variable;
  6357   bool message_p;
  6358   specpdl_ref count = SPECPDL_INDEX ();
  6359   struct timespec start;
  6360 
  6361   eassert (weak_hash_tables == NULL);
  6362 
  6363   if (garbage_collection_inhibited)
  6364     return;
  6365 
  6366   eassert(mark_stack_empty_p ());
  6367 
  6368   /* Record this function, so it appears on the profiler's backtraces.  */
  6369   record_in_backtrace (QAutomatic_GC, 0, 0);
  6370 
  6371   /* Don't keep undo information around forever.
  6372      Do this early on, so it is no problem if the user quits.  */
  6373   FOR_EACH_LIVE_BUFFER (tail, buffer)
  6374     compact_buffer (XBUFFER (buffer));
  6375 
  6376   byte_ct tot_before = (profiler_memory_running
  6377                         ? total_bytes_of_live_objects ()
  6378                         : (byte_ct) -1);
  6379 
  6380   start = current_timespec ();
  6381 
  6382   /* In case user calls debug_print during GC,
  6383      don't let that cause a recursive GC.  */
  6384   consing_until_gc = HI_THRESHOLD;
  6385 
  6386   /* Save what's currently displayed in the echo area.  Don't do that
  6387      if we are GC'ing because we've run out of memory, since
  6388      push_message will cons, and we might have no memory for that.  */
  6389   if (NILP (Vmemory_full))
  6390     {
  6391       message_p = push_message ();
  6392       record_unwind_protect_void (pop_message_unwind);
  6393     }
  6394   else
  6395     message_p = false;
  6396 
  6397   /* Save a copy of the contents of the stack, for debugging.  */
  6398 #if MAX_SAVE_STACK > 0
  6399   if (NILP (Vpurify_flag))
  6400     {
  6401       char const *stack;
  6402       ptrdiff_t stack_size;
  6403       if (&stack_top_variable < stack_bottom)
  6404         {
  6405           stack = &stack_top_variable;
  6406           stack_size = stack_bottom - &stack_top_variable;
  6407         }
  6408       else
  6409         {
  6410           stack = stack_bottom;
  6411           stack_size = &stack_top_variable - stack_bottom;
  6412         }
  6413       if (stack_size <= MAX_SAVE_STACK)
  6414         {
  6415           if (stack_copy_size < stack_size)
  6416             {
  6417               stack_copy = xrealloc (stack_copy, stack_size);
  6418               stack_copy_size = stack_size;
  6419             }
  6420           no_sanitize_memcpy (stack_copy, stack, stack_size);
  6421         }
  6422     }
  6423 #endif /* MAX_SAVE_STACK > 0 */
  6424 
  6425   if (garbage_collection_messages)
  6426     message1_nolog ("Garbage collecting...");
  6427 
  6428   block_input ();
  6429 
  6430   shrink_regexp_cache ();
  6431 
  6432   gc_in_progress = 1;
  6433 
  6434   /* Mark all the special slots that serve as the roots of accessibility.  */
  6435 
  6436   struct gc_root_visitor visitor = { .visit = mark_object_root_visitor };
  6437   visit_static_gc_roots (visitor);
  6438 
  6439   mark_pinned_objects ();
  6440   mark_pinned_symbols ();
  6441   mark_lread ();
  6442   mark_terminals ();
  6443   mark_kboards ();
  6444   mark_threads ();
  6445 #ifdef HAVE_PGTK
  6446   mark_pgtkterm ();
  6447 #endif
  6448 
  6449 #ifdef USE_GTK
  6450   xg_mark_data ();
  6451 #endif
  6452 
  6453 #ifdef HAVE_HAIKU
  6454   mark_haiku_display ();
  6455 #endif
  6456 
  6457 #ifdef HAVE_WINDOW_SYSTEM
  6458   mark_fringe_data ();
  6459 #endif
  6460 
  6461 #ifdef HAVE_X_WINDOWS
  6462   mark_xterm ();
  6463   mark_xselect ();
  6464 #endif
  6465 
  6466 #ifdef HAVE_NS
  6467   mark_nsterm ();
  6468 #endif
  6469 
  6470   /* Everything is now marked, except for the data in font caches,
  6471      undo lists, and finalizers.  The first two are compacted by
  6472      removing an items which aren't reachable otherwise.  */
  6473 
  6474   compact_font_caches ();
  6475 
  6476   FOR_EACH_LIVE_BUFFER (tail, buffer)
  6477     {
  6478       struct buffer *nextb = XBUFFER (buffer);
  6479       if (!EQ (BVAR (nextb, undo_list), Qt))
  6480         bset_undo_list (nextb, compact_undo_list (BVAR (nextb, undo_list)));
  6481       /* Now that we have stripped the elements that need not be
  6482          in the undo_list any more, we can finally mark the list.  */
  6483       mark_object (BVAR (nextb, undo_list));
  6484     }
  6485 
  6486   /* Now pre-sweep finalizers.  Here, we add any unmarked finalizers
  6487      to doomed_finalizers so we can run their associated functions
  6488      after GC.  It's important to scan finalizers at this stage so
  6489      that we can be sure that unmarked finalizers are really
  6490      unreachable except for references from their associated functions
  6491      and from other finalizers.  */
  6492 
  6493   queue_doomed_finalizers (&doomed_finalizers, &finalizers);
  6494   mark_finalizer_list (&doomed_finalizers);
  6495 
  6496   /* Must happen after all other marking and before gc_sweep.  */
  6497   mark_and_sweep_weak_table_contents ();
  6498   eassert (weak_hash_tables == NULL);
  6499 
  6500   eassert (mark_stack_empty_p ());
  6501 
  6502   gc_sweep ();
  6503 
  6504   unmark_main_thread ();
  6505 
  6506   gc_in_progress = 0;
  6507 
  6508   consing_until_gc = gc_threshold
  6509     = consing_threshold (gc_cons_threshold, Vgc_cons_percentage, 0);
  6510 
  6511   /* Unblock *after* re-setting `consing_until_gc` in case `unblock_input`
  6512      signals an error (see bug#43389).  */
  6513   unblock_input ();
  6514 
  6515   if (garbage_collection_messages && NILP (Vmemory_full))
  6516     {
  6517       if (message_p || minibuf_level > 0)
  6518         restore_message ();
  6519       else
  6520         message1_nolog ("Garbage collecting...done");
  6521     }
  6522 
  6523   unbind_to (count, Qnil);
  6524 
  6525   /* GC is complete: now we can run our finalizer callbacks.  */
  6526   run_finalizers (&doomed_finalizers);
  6527 
  6528 #ifdef HAVE_WINDOW_SYSTEM
  6529   /* Eject unused image cache entries.  */
  6530   image_prune_animation_caches (false);
  6531 #endif
  6532 
  6533   if (!NILP (Vpost_gc_hook))
  6534     {
  6535       specpdl_ref gc_count = inhibit_garbage_collection ();
  6536       safe_run_hooks (Qpost_gc_hook);
  6537       unbind_to (gc_count, Qnil);
  6538     }
  6539 
  6540   /* Accumulate statistics.  */
  6541   if (FLOATP (Vgc_elapsed))
  6542     {
  6543       static struct timespec gc_elapsed;
  6544       gc_elapsed = timespec_add (gc_elapsed,
  6545                                  timespec_sub (current_timespec (), start));
  6546       Vgc_elapsed = make_float (timespectod (gc_elapsed));
  6547     }
  6548 
  6549   gcs_done++;
  6550 
  6551   /* Collect profiling data.  */
  6552   if (tot_before != (byte_ct) -1)
  6553     {
  6554       byte_ct tot_after = total_bytes_of_live_objects ();
  6555       if (tot_after < tot_before)
  6556         malloc_probe (min (tot_before - tot_after, SIZE_MAX));
  6557     }
  6558 }
  6559 
  6560 DEFUN ("garbage-collect", Fgarbage_collect, Sgarbage_collect, 0, 0, "",
  6561        doc: /* Reclaim storage for Lisp objects no longer needed.
  6562 Garbage collection happens automatically if you cons more than
  6563 `gc-cons-threshold' bytes of Lisp data since previous garbage collection.
  6564 `garbage-collect' normally returns a list with info on amount of space in use,
  6565 where each entry has the form (NAME SIZE USED FREE), where:
  6566 - NAME is a symbol describing the kind of objects this entry represents,
  6567 - SIZE is the number of bytes used by each one,
  6568 - USED is the number of those objects that were found live in the heap,
  6569 - FREE is the number of those objects that are not live but that Emacs
  6570   keeps around for future allocations (maybe because it does not know how
  6571   to return them to the OS).
  6572 
  6573 However, if there was overflow in pure space, and Emacs was dumped
